JAMES DROVER BARNETT
AND

REVISED AND EDITED BY
EDWARD T. E. BESLEY, ESQ.,

LONDON:
STEVENS AND SONS, LIMITED, 119, CHANCERY LANE.

Held on Monday, July 27th, 1891, and following days.

BEFORE the RIGHT HON. Sir

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

573.
EDWARD PINTER (56)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully attempt
ing to obtain Â£40,000 from
Edwin William Streeter by false pretences, with intent to defraud.â€”
Three Months' Imprisonment.

p.hi: For case tried in this Court this day see Surrey cases.

div1.p:
577.
HENRY RICHARDS (25)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

CHRISSY WILKS . I am assistant at a hairdresser's and jeweller's at. 3A, Sidney Place, Leicester Squareâ€”on 1st July, between 3 and 4 p.m., the prisoner came in and produced a watch chain, and asked for a swivel for it, which I gave him, and charged him sixpenceâ€”he gave me this two-shilling coin (produced); I noticed that it was bad, and said that I had not got changeâ€”I recognised him as having given me a bad one before, and having seen the chain before I gave him in chargeâ€”he had been there on July 18, and shown me the same chain, and asked for a swivel, which I put on and charged him sixpence, and he paid me with this bad half-crown; I afterwards found it was bad, and kept it distinct.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. On 18th June I did not find the half-crown was bad till you had goneâ€”I put it with other money, but there was no other half-crown.

ALICE WILLIAMS . I am an assistant at the same shopâ€”on 18th June the prisoner came in, and after he had gone this half-crown was found in the till on top of the other moneyâ€”I also saw him come on July 18th and produce a chain.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to H. M. Mintâ€”these half-crowns are both counterfeit.

WILLIAM BAKER (P 10). On July 1st, at 4.20 p.m., I was called to 3A, Sidney Place, and the prisoner was given into my chargeâ€”I asked him, how the coin came into his possession; he said he changed a half-sovereign on Saturday night, and must have got it thenâ€”he gave his address, 93, Leather Laneâ€”I found on him two good florins and a penny.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his defence, stated that he had no idea that the first half-crown was bad, being nearly blind, and that he took the second one in change.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction at Chelmsford on November 2nd, 1886, of feloniously uttering counterfeit coin, when he was sentenced to five years' penal servitude.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude,

578.
WILLIAM GREGORY (43)
, Feloniously making twenty pieces of counterfeit coin resembling half-crowns.

WILLIAM GEORGE MASON . I have known the prisoner three or four weeksâ€”I met him first about the last day of June on London Bridgeâ€”I had some talk with him, and went with him to Victoria Parkâ€”on the way he gave me a half-crown to get a two penny loafâ€”I went into a baker's shop and offered it in payment; she broke it in the tester, and gave me the piecesâ€”I went back and gave them to Gregory, and told him; he said nothing, but threw them into the water in Victoria Parkâ€”he said he would put me in the way of earning two or three shillings in doing counterfeit coin, and he produced a half-crown and said, "This is a bad one "â€”he asked me to go to his house, and on the way he gave me a half-crown, and said, "Go to the post-office and get some stamps "â€”I did not go because I thought I could not change it, but I went next door and got two penny eggs, and the woman gave me 2s. 4d. changeâ€”the prisoner was opposite, and I went with him to 62, Queensberry Street, Islingtonâ€”he had only one room there as a sleeping and living room, and I occupied it with him till I was taken in custodyâ€”he said his name was Gregory, and I said my name was Masonâ€”when I arrived there I stopped outside and he went in and came out and brought out five half-crowns, and gave me one of themâ€”he filed the edges of them, and went into shops and passed them, all five, one at a timeâ€”after that we went back to his lodgingâ€”three or four days afterwards he made a mould for some shillings, and put it on the hob to dry, and then poured some metal in, and made two or three shillingsâ€”he also made a mould for three half-crowns, and I saw him make about a dozen and a half shillings and half-crownsâ€”I went with him and saw him buy some metal like solder, which he melted in a little potâ€”July 10th, the Friday before I was taken, was the last time I saw the half-crown mould usedâ€”he poured metal into it

â€”they were afterwards filed and silveredâ€”I saw some blue stone and water, and he put a zinc thing in, and put some copper wire to it, and the coins at the end of the wireâ€”there was some silver in a cupâ€”I went out with him on Saturday, the 11th, about one o'clockâ€”he took out twelve half-crowns with him, and left eight in a tin box under the washhand-standâ€”that box was used for keeping the metal inâ€”when we were out he carried the coins, and gave me one at a timeâ€”I took them to twelve post offices, and passed ten of themâ€”I went to one post-office at the corner of Balls Pond Road, and got 5s. worth of stamps, and put down a bad half-crown and 2s. 6d. in good moneyâ€”I gave the stamps to the prisoner, and he put them in his pocketâ€”on the same afternoon I went to a post-office in High Street, Stoke Newington, and gave a half-crown to a man who said it was bad, who took the stamps back and gave back the coinâ€”we then went to a post-office at Stamford Hillâ€”the prisoner remained oppositeâ€”I asked for some stamps, and the young man behind the counter broke the coinâ€”the prisoner threw the pieces over the hoardingâ€”all those visits were on the afternoon of the 11thâ€”we went to Essex Road that evening, and the prisoner sent me to buy a cup and saucerâ€”the prisoner stood two or three yards offâ€”the coin was found to be bad, and I was taken in custody, and saw the prisoner going away towards homeâ€”he had said to me, "If you are caught I will throw the mould into the canal."

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You first met me on the last day of Juneâ€”I said I was hungry, and you took me to a public-house and gave me somethingâ€”when we had passed one half-crown we went home for moreâ€”I have been convicted of stealing two pigeons.

JOHN SMITH . I am a clerk at the post-office, 261, Balls Pond Roadâ€”about 2nd or 3rd July the prisoner came in for five shillings worth of stampsâ€”my sister served him; he gave her two half-crowns, and she handed one to me, and asked me in his presence if it was goodâ€”I tried it between my teeth, and said, "No"â€”it was grittyâ€”it was handed back, and good money paidâ€”on July 22nd I went to the police-station, and picked the prisoner out from a number of men.

JAMES COLE . I am a clerk at the post-office, 39, High Street, Stoke Newingtonâ€”on 11th July Mason came in for four shillingsworth of stampsâ€”he tendered a half-crown, twelve penny pieces, and some six-pencesâ€”after he left I found the half-crown was badâ€”the prisoner was brought back, and I took the stamps awayâ€”I had seen the prisoner a fortnight before, when I served him with some postage-stampsâ€”I do not know what he paid with, but there was a bad half-crown.

LILA SCUTT . I am a clerk in the Stamford Hill post-officeâ€”on. the afternoon of 11th July a boy about Mason's size came in and asked for four shillingsworth of stamps, and gave me a bad half-crown and sixpence and twelvepenceâ€”I found out immediately that the half-crown was bad, and called him back and gave him the piecesâ€”I saw it broken in the testerâ€”I recognise the prisoner as having given me bad money.

MARGARET OATES . I assist my son in a china-shop, 140, Essex Road, Islingtonâ€”on the night of 11th July I was outside the shop servingâ€”Mason came and asked for a penny cup and saucer, and tendered a half-crown; I asked if he had any coppers; he said, "No "â€”I handed the half-crown to my son, who said, "Come here, my lad; where did you get
this from?"â€”he said, "My mother gave it to me"â€”he threw it down, and broke a piece off with the heel of his boot on the wooden floorâ€”a constable came and took the boyâ€”this is the half-crown,

WILLIAM AUSTIN (N 353). On 11th July I was on duty at night in Essex Road, and saw Mason outside No. 140â€”he picked up a couple of saucers outside, and tendered a half-crown to Mrs. Oatesâ€”I took him into the shop, and took him into custodyâ€”I then saw the prisoner about twelve yards from the shop, walking behind meâ€”I took the boy to the station, and then went to 62, Queensberry Street, and saw a woman thereâ€”about five minutes afterwards the prisoner came in as I was going out; I said, "Have you a son here?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "He is detained at Upper Street Police-station"â€”he said, "What, with that half-crown?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "I hope it is a good one"â€”we then got to the station, and he said, "I gave him the half-crown; I did not know it was a bad one. "
Cross-examined. I went into your room at your invitation.

FOSTER ISAACSON . I live at 5, St. Paul's Road, Islington, and am a cigar. merchantâ€”on 11th July I went to the post-office at 261, Balls Pond Road, and changed a half-sovereign, and received two half-crowns, two florins, and one shilling; I had nothing but gold at that timeâ€”I after
wards looked at the half-crowns and found one of them badâ€”I gave it to Sergeant Smithâ€”this is it; I marked it.

JAMES SMITH (Police Sergeant N). I took the prisoner on a warrant on 15th Julyâ€”I read it to him; he said, "Who gave you that information?"â€”I said, "William George Davis, your boy"â€”he said, "That is not his name; we shall see by-and-bye"â€”I alluded to the boy Mason, who first gave his name Gregory, then Davis, and then Mason, which is his correct nameâ€”I went with Detective Dyke to the first floor back room at 62, Queensberry Street, and got in with a key which I found on the prisonerâ€”I searched the room, and found this file, pipe, piece of looking-glass, jelly-pot, and copper wire; some in a cupboard and the others under the bed.
WILLIAM AUSTIN (Re-examined). Half or three quarters of an hour elapsed between my leaving Mrs. Oates' shop and going to 62, Queensberry Street.
Cross-examined. You were not really detained at the station, you were there on behalf of your boy.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin to the Mintâ€”the coins are both counterfeit, and from the same mouldâ€”this file could be used in the manufacture of counterfeit coin, and there is metal on itâ€”there is no liquid in these pots now, but the blue liquid was probably sul
phate of copper, which is used in the silvering process.

Prisoner's Defence. Everything the boy has said is entirely false; he states this to clear himself. Everything he says contradicts the other. He is relating a conversation which he heard between me and another person relating to years gone by.

GUILTY . He had been several times convicted, and sentenced to six years and ten years' penal servitude.â€”
Twelve Years' Penal Servitude.

579.
JOHN SMITH (17) and
CHARLES RAEMERS (20)
PLEADED GUILTY
to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Joseph Vesty, and stealing a quantity of clothing, value Â£4 10s., his property.â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.

580.
FREDERICK CROMER (38)
, to unlawfully obtaining two swords from
Arthur George Lock, and other swords from other persons, by false pretences.â€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Two Months, without Hard Labour.

581.
JOHN EDWARD LEONARD HARMAN TITCHMARSH
, to feloniously marrying
Eliza Phelan, his wife being then aliveâ€”
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Two Days' Imprisonment. And

(582).
JOHN GROUT (32) and
GEORGE BEAUMONT (22)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Lane Lea, with intent to steal.
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.] GROUT also
PLEADED GUILTY
to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Adelaide Heymanson, and stealing a musical box and a pair of scissors, the goods of
Rebecca Holland. BEAUMONT also PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at this Court in June, 1880.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour each.

583.
ERICH HEUSER (50)
, Unlawfully attempting to procure certain acts of indecency.

584.
JAMES LANDEN (18)
, Indecently assaulting
Elizabeth Alice Fletcher.
NOT GUILTY .

585.
CATHERINE BOWLEY (17),
SARAH ANN HARNETT (15),
MARY ANN FURBY (16),
ALICE EVERSON (15), and
MARY ANN DONOVAN (15),
PLEADED GUILTY to
a burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Frederick Stoy, and stealing a watch and other articles, value Â£42. BOWLEY* and FURBYâ€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.
HARNETT, EVERSON, and DONOVANâ€”
Ten Days' Imprisonment and Three Years in a Reformatory.

586.
JULIA DONOVAN was indicted
for the same offence.

GEORGE ABBOTT (Sergeant F 6). On 7th July I was in the station; I had received information of a burglary committed in the Lansdown Road, Notting Hillâ€”about half-past seven a.m. Mary Ann Donovan and the prisoner came, and Mary Ann said, "Are four girls locked up here for burglary?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”she said, "I was with them when they broke into the house, and I wish to give myself up "â€”the prisoner said, "I was with the others, but I did not go into the house; I waited outside with a girl named Annie Cullen, who lives in St. Clement's Road, and watched to see if a policeman or anybody else was about whilst the others were inside "â€”I took these statements in writing, and they signed them.

WILLIAM PRINCE (Detective F). On 6th July I had received informa
tion of this burglaryâ€”I went with two other officers to the house, and watched the pavement below from the drawing-roomâ€”I saw the pri
soner and the five other girls who have pleaded guilty in Chichester Road, which is opposite the houseâ€”they were playing about in the road, and occasionally one or two would walk round in front of the house; when a man in uniform came by they would walk away and come back againâ€”the prisoner did not go round by the house, but she was playing about
with the othersâ€”when it began to get dusk I missed them; I could not see them from where I was then.
The Prisoner's Defence. I did not know what they were going into the house for. I never had any of the stolen property. I know nothing at all about it, nor what they had.
MRS. DONOVAN. I am the prisoner's motherâ€”she is a good girl, only fourteen years old, and has done nothing wrongâ€”she went away with Furby, who said she would be well done for.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the JURY
on account of her youth. The police sergeant stated that he had reason to believe she had been led into it.â€”
Two Days' Imprisonment.

587.
GEORGE SMITH (48)
, Unlawfully attempting to commit a burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Walton. Second Count, for the unlawful possession of housebreaking implements.

JOHN WALTON, JUN . I am a clerk, and live at 15, Landrock Road, Hornseyâ€”on 29th June, about half-past eleven at night, I was with a friend in Ridge Road, Hornsey, which runs parallel with Mount View Road, where my father livesâ€”I heard a whistle, and we ran in the direction, and just before getting to the corner saw the prisoner running down Granville Street into Ridge Road; another man was ahead of him, and a constable in chaseâ€”I got up to him just as the constable stopped him, and went to the station with himâ€”I afterwards went to my father's house, 137, Mount View Road, and found the door broken, as if by a jemmyâ€”the house was a furnished house, but had been unoccupied for some timeâ€”I had passed the house three times the previous day, and it was then all right.

DAVID DUNBAR (Y 450). On 29th June, between half-past eleven and twelve, I was in Mount View Road, Hornsey, and in consequence of in
formation I went down Mount View Roadâ€”I saw the prisoner with another man not in custody, standing under a lampâ€”I at once gave chase, and pursued them along Mount View Road, turning into Gran
ville Road, and caught the prisoner in Ridge Road; the other escapedâ€”I seized the prisoner; we had a struggleâ€”he raised his left arm and was about to strike me with this jemmyâ€”another constable came up and seized him by the armâ€”I took him into custody, and told him he would be charged with attempting to break into 137, Mount View Roadâ€”he made no replyâ€”I searched him at the station, and found this jemmy in his pocketâ€”I examined the door of the prosecutor's house, and found on it marks corresponding with both these jemmies; I also found some matches on the floor, which had been struck, and the prisoner had similar matches in his pocketâ€”I had passed this house at six that morning, and it was quite right then; the gate was locked with handcuffs.
Cross-examined. I produce the matches; they had been struck on the doorway and windowâ€”I did not see you do anything.

ALFRED DIXON (Detective Y). I heard the whistle, and ran in the direction, and saw the prisoner standing with Dunbar; the prisoner had this large jemmy in his left hand raised, about to strike him; I secured him, and took him to Hornsey Station.

WILLIAM DESBOROUGH (Y 217). On the evening of 29th June I passed the house, 137, Mount View Road about a quarter-past nineâ€”I examined the door and found the premises all safe and the gate lockedâ€”at half-past eleven I saw the marks on the door and the gate open.

p.rs: I Plead Guilty to having the jemmy on me, but to nothing else.

div1.p:
588.
WALTER BILLINGS (61)
, Corruptly making a false declara
tion. Second count, by false pretences causing
William George Stacey and
Francis William Finney to execute a promissory note for Â£250, with intent to defraud.

RIVERS MONTAGU TURNBULL . I am a solicitor, and a commissioner to administer oaths in the Supreme Court of Judicature, at Mitre Court, Templeâ€”on 30th January I went to the office of the prosecutor's solicitor in the same building, and the prisoner made this declaration before me, and signed it in my presenceâ€”I said, "I suppose you know all about this, it has been read over to you?"â€”he said, "Yes."

WILLIAM GEORGE STACEY . I am a commercial clerk, at 70, Ampthill Road, Tottenhamâ€”I have known the prisoner for seven monthsâ€”about the end of last December he said he was in want of money; that he had a reversion, under his brother's will, of a considerable amount, and that he wanted a loanâ€”he told me he had not charged the reversionâ€”in consequence of what he told me I signed this promissory note at his requestâ€”I should not have signed it except for what he told meâ€”I signed it at my City office, and handed it to Mr. Finney, an old friend of mine, who introduced the prisoner to meâ€”proceedings were instituted against me in respect of this note, and judgment signed against me in default.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. The first advance and promissory note were for Â£100, and then subsequently you came and made a statement, and believing it, and on your declaration we agreed to lend our names for you to receive Â£250â€”the note for Â£100 was destroyed at the time the note for Â£250 was givenâ€”the note was made on 30th January; evidently the declaration had been made before I was asked for the noteâ€”a bill with three names is not negotiable till it is completeâ€”the declaration was made before the others signedâ€”I was to have 5 per cent, interest for signing the note.

FRANCIS WILLIAM FINNEY . I am a manufacturer's agent, living at 158, Malpas Road, Brockleyâ€”I have known the prisoner for some yearsâ€”he told me he was in want of money, and said he had a sixth share under his brother's will; there was about Â£25,000; after paying off certain legacies it left him Â£18,000 or Â£19,000â€”he said he had never charged itâ€”in consequence of what he told me I signed a promissory note for Â£250 at his requestâ€”on that day I attended at 5, Mitre Court Chambers with the prisoner and Mr. Robinsonâ€”I saw Mr. Turnbull thereâ€”the prisoner made a declaration that he had not dealt with his reversionary interest in any shape or form; that was read to him in my presenceâ€”I nut my signature to the promissory noteâ€”Mr. Robinson gave him for the promissory note a cheque which he cashed in Fleet Streetâ€”the prisoner did not pay" the promissory note; proceedings were taken against me, and judgment was given in defaultâ€”the prisoner gave me Â£10 as considera
tion
â€”if he had not told me he had not dealt with the reversionary interest in any way I should not have signed the promissory note.

By the JURY. Only Mr. Stacey's signature was on the note when I signed itâ€”the prisoner had Â£100 first, and when he had the Â£250 he paid the Â£100 off, because he had it from a different party, the second time I think; I could not tell what he paid for the Â£250 accommodationâ€”I was a manufacturer's agent at this timeâ€”I am not in the habit of taking money for finding people to pick up billsâ€”I should not have signed my name to this bill unless the prisoner had wanted to go into busi
ness with me: he was going to put Â£600 down to join me in businessâ€”I thought his story about the reversion was all right, as I had known him as a gentleman for many yearsâ€”the declaration was made before I signed this noteâ€”when I signed the note two more signatures were wanting.

WILLIAM JOHN HELLIER . I am managing clerk to Lawford, Water-house, and Lawford, solicitors, 28, Austin Friarsâ€”they are solicitors to Mr. Radford, who was trustee under the will of Albert Billings, the prisoner's deceased brotherâ€”the prisoner at one time was entitled to a reversionary interest in one-sixth share, subject to the life interest of the widow, and her right to appoint a sum of Â£1,000â€”the prisoner borrowed on mortgage on his interest, and I was instructed to pay off that mortgage, taking a reassignment, and clearing up some other claims against the prisoner, which I didâ€”I afterwards took a clear mortgage, which is still existingâ€”in 1882 he sold to Mrs. Emma Radford his equity of redemp
tion in the reversion, subject to the previous mortgage, for Â£300â€”on that occasion the prisoner was represented by a solicitor, Charles Edward Smith, who perused the documents, and gave him the figuresâ€”Mrs. Radford then really gave more than it was worthâ€”the reversion was then sold for Â£800; the tenant for life was aged 41, and the residuary estate was invested in debenture stock, which has increased something like 20 per cent, in valueâ€”the figures were represented by Â£680, and the value of that reversion would exceed Â£1,100 or Â£1,200â€”that is nearly ten years agoâ€”it is absolutely untrue for the prisoner to say that he had in no way dealt with itâ€”at that time he was not interested in it at all; he had parted with all his interest in it.
Cross-examined. Your sister did not tell you it was held over for you; that is imaginationâ€”Mrs. Radford is your sister.
Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I did not intend to defraud. "

MARY BURGESS . I am single; the prisoner is my masterâ€”Mr. Finney came to our place with Mr. Stacey, and said he had made arrangements with Mr. Robinson that they were going to pay so much a month, and that that was the agreementâ€”I was in the hall, and heard Mr. Finney say he was going to make an arrangement with Mr. Robinson for Mr. Stacey to pay so much money down and so much afterwardsâ€”Mr. Robinson is one of the solicitors I supposeâ€”they have taken and sold the furniture, which is Mrs. Billings's property; it is her separate estate.

p.hi: ruled that the first count of the indictment was bad, as it neither stated that the declaration was made before a Commissioner for Oaths, nor that it was false in a material particular. Upon the second count the

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

589.
CHARLES VALENTINE SMITH (40)
, Feloniously marrying
Ann Riley during the lifetime of his wife.

ANN RILEY . I am a widow, living at 19, Rupert Road, Hollowayâ€”I have a laundry businessâ€”on 25th December I went through the ceremony of marriage with the prisoner at St. Judo's Church, Gray's Inn Roadâ€”this is the certificateâ€”I lived with him as his wife at 19, Rupert Road, till the middle of April, when we agreed' to separate, because we were continually quarrelingâ€”while I was with him, a month or six weeks after our wedding, I heard he was a married man from something he said, and I went to Somerset House, searched the register, and found he was marriedâ€”I got this copy of the certificate there, (this was the certificate of a marriage on 8th October, 1882, at the parish church, Islington, between Charles Valentine Smith and Rebecca Taylor)â€”I did not know when I married him that he had been married before.

Cross-examined. I came to your lodging once, and your landlady said something about your being married, but you told me you had lived with a woman for eight yearsâ€”you told me that when you first met meâ€”you have four wives living nowâ€”I came to your place with your third wifeâ€”we separated in the middle of April on account of your vile tongueâ€”I have had nineteen children; sixteen are living.

JOHN COUOHMAN (Detective Sergeant Y). About half-past twelve on the 20th I took the prisoner into custody, and said he would be charged with bigamy and felony, and whatever he said might be used in evidence against himâ€”he said, "It is quite right about my having a wife living; but she is no wife of mine, as she is a prostitute, walking the Euston Road, and she" (referring to Mrs. Riley) "knew I was a married man when we got married"â€”I have compared one of these certificates with the register at St. Mary's, Islington, and the other with the register at St. Jude's, Gray's Inn Road; they are correct.

MRS. SHEAN. I am the wife of John J. Shean, 25, Seaton Street, Hampstead Roadâ€”on 8th October, 1882, I was present at St. Mary's Church, Islington, at the wedding of the prisoner with Rebecca Taylorâ€”I saw her at the Police-court about three weeks agoâ€”I was one of the witnesses who signed the register; I was Sarah Drewitt at that time; I have married sinceâ€”I saw them after their little girl was born, and again about three years afterwards.
JOHN COUCHMAN (Re-examined by the COURT). The prisoner was married previous to 1882â€”that wife was supposed to be dead in 1882â€”he has been married four times I am told.

GUILTY .â€”The prisoner then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at this Court in December, 1869.

p.hi:
There was another indictment against him for stealing a watch, the property of Ann Riley.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
590.
JOHN SOER (91)
, Unlawfully and indecently assaulting
Alice Jane Gardner, a girl under thirteen.

591.
LOUISA NORTH(23)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully endeavour
ing to conceal the birth of her child.

She received a good character.â€”
Discharged on her own recognizance.
The prisoner teas also charged on the Coroner's inquisition for the manslaughter of the said child, upon which
MR. NICHOLSON,
for the prosecution, offered no evidence.

592.
JAMES BEMMER (38)
, Feloniously wounding
Eliza Saunders, with intent to murder. Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

"ELIZA SAUNDERS . I am a laundry woman, and live at 39, Manchester Road, Notting Hillâ€”I lived with the prisoner as his wife till about five months agoâ€”on Saturday night, 27th June last, I was out with the prisoner and returned to 39, Manchester Road about twenty minutes to twelve; he then asked me to go out with him againâ€”I said no, I was not going any more, for my baby was illâ€”he said, "If you don't go out, you b-----, I will do for you"â€”he then hit me under the ear, and threw me on the bedâ€”I did not know that he had a knife until I felt the blood comeâ€”I screamed, and an old lady that I lived with came to my assistanceâ€”this took place in the back parlourâ€”my two children were in bed at the time, but I did not know they were there; Harry was one of themâ€”the prisoner was not living there with me at this time; he came there sometimes; he met me that night at work; he was generally there when I left off work.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. On the night this happened I did not say I was tired of my life, and I would do for myself and my two children also; I never took up the knifeâ€”I never saw the knife till I went into the room with the policemanâ€”after receiving the wound I ran out into the street to go to the doctor's; I met the policeman, and he took me backâ€”I had some bruises on my arm, but that had nothing to do with this; it was in a row that I and the old lady hadâ€”on the Wednesday evening before this I was at his place all night, and it was a wonder I was not killed then.

HARRY SAUNDERS . I am eight years old, and live with my mother at 39, Manchester Roadâ€”on this Saturday night I was in bed in the back parlour when my mother came in with the prisonerâ€”I saw him push her in the back first, then he took up a knife on a box where mother put the washing; this is itâ€”he made a stroke with it, and then dropped it on the floorâ€”she screamed out, and went into Mr. Clark's roomâ€”I saw blood on the bedâ€”after hitting her he said, "Now I have done it!"â€”I was sitting up in bed when I saw this.

JANE PEARL . I am a widow; I live at 39, Manchester Roadâ€”Eliza Saunders lodged there with me; she occupied the back parlour; she is no relation to me; the child has been brought up to call me "Grannie"â€”I know the prisonerâ€”on Saturday, 27th June, about half-past eleven, the prosecutrix came in with the prisonerâ€”they then went out together to the Bull public-houseâ€”they were out for about ten minutes; it was about twenty minutes to twelve when they brought in a pint of beerâ€”they came straight through into the back kitchenâ€”he asked for a shirt which I had washedâ€”she went out of the back kitchen into the back

parlour; he followed herâ€”I heard her say, "I don't want you following me"â€”the back parlour was where she slept and where the little boy sleptâ€”he was in bed; he had not been in bed long; my son had put him to bedâ€”the prisoner said, "Are you not going out again?"â€”she said, "No, I am not, not to have a blowing up when I come back," meaning that I should be cross with herâ€”he then said, "Then you don't want me," and then I heard a dreadful scream from her, momentarilyâ€”I then new into the back parlour, thinking he had hit herâ€”he was leaning over her on the bedâ€”she was bleeding, and I felt blood on my armâ€”I was very much frightenedâ€”I said, "Good God, Bemmer, what have you done?"â€”he said, "I have done it, and I meant to do it"â€”my son's wife, Mrs. Clark, then came inâ€”Saunders ran out as soon as she couldâ€”Mrs. Clark hit the prisoner on the back, but he would not release her till my son came in, and he pulled him awayâ€”a police
man afterwards cameâ€”I saw that the prisoner had something in his hand, but I could not say what it wasâ€”the box the boy speaks of was really two boxes covered with a cloth and used as a table.

SARAH CLARK . I lodge at 39, Manchester Roadâ€”on Saturday, 27th June, between half-past eleven and twelve, I heard a scream, and went to Saunders' room, and saw her and the prisoner struggling together partly on the bedâ€”I tried to take his arm from herâ€”finding I could not called my husbandâ€”the prosecutrix was under, and the prisoner was leaning over herâ€”I heard something fall on the floor in the struggle;. it sounded like steel and the handle togetherâ€”when Mrs. Pearl came in she asked what he was doingâ€”he said, "It is done, and I meant to do it."

HARRY JAMES CLARK . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”on 27th June, about 11.30, I saw the prosecutrix come in with the prisonerâ€”I did not see where they came fromâ€”I was in the front parlourâ€”I did not hear the prisoner say anything when he came inâ€”later I heard a screamâ€”my wife went into the prosecutrix's roomâ€”I heard her call me, and then I went in and caught the prisoner by the collarâ€”he was standing by the fireplace, away from the bedâ€”I said, "What the b----hell have you been doing, Jim?"â€”he said, "It is done; where is Eliza? let me kiss her before I go"â€”I sent for a policeman, and stayed with the prisoner till he came.

GEORGE FREDERICK MURRELL . I am house physician at the West London Hospitalâ€”the prosecutrix was brought there about a quarter to two on Sunday morning, 28th Juneâ€”I examined her; on the chin I found a small superficial wound about an inch long, and below the chin I found a deeper wound about three inches long, which had turned down a flap of skinâ€”it was not really a deep wound; there had been a good deal of hemorrhageâ€”the wounds themselves were not dangerousâ€”they would be caused by a sharp instrument such as this knifeâ€”I attended to her and sent her away.

ALFRED TIDD (X 123). I met the prosecutrix a little before twelve on the evening of 27th June; I went with her to 39, Manchester Road, and there took the prisoner into custodyâ€”he said to prosecutrix, "You have done it yourself."
ARTHUR KIRK (K 478). I was sent for to 39, Manchester Road, and saw the prisoner in the custody of Tiddâ€”the prosecutrix picked up this, knife, and handed it to me.

GEORGE JENKINS (Inspector X). On 27th June I was at Notting Dale Stationâ€”the prisoner was brought in and chargedâ€”he wished to make a statementâ€”I cautioned him, and took down this statement in writing, and read it to him, and he put his mark to it. (Read: "The first thing this evening, at 9.20, I met Eliza Saunders at the Nut Brown public-house, Bramley Road. We went in and had refreshment; we then walked on till we got to the York public-house in the same road; we met a friend who asked her to have another drink; she declined, we went to 39. I asked her for my shirt. She said, 'We will go and get it.' I said, 'All right, put your coat on, and we will have a joint of meat.' We then went to the Old Black Bull and had some ale, and brought back a pint of porter for the old woman. Mrs. Saunders said, 'Jim, I will kill my two children.' She took up a knife, and then she screamed and said, 'Jim, I have done it,' and then ran out of the room."
Prisoner's defence. I have spoken the truth in what I have said; what the boy has said is quite wrong.

GUILTY
of unlawful wounding â€”
Five Months' Hard Labour.

593.
PATRICK COSTELLO (60)
, Unlawfully attempting to ad
minister poison to
Jane Bass, so as to endanger her life. Second Count, So as to occasion actual bodily harm, and to injure, aggrieve, and annoy.

ETHEL LILY ROTTNDTREE . I am eleven years old, and live with my mother in London Fieldsâ€”on Friday afternoon, 26th June, about twenty minutes to four, I was in Mare Street, Hackneyâ€”the prisoner came up to me with a paper bag in his hand; he said, "Will you give these two buns to that woman standing at the corner selling flowers?"â€”he gave me the bag: and walked awayâ€”I went and gave the bag to the lady; I said something to her, and then walked awayâ€”about ten minutes after
wards she came after me, and spoke to me, and showed me the bunsâ€”one of them was broken; there was some green-looking stuff insideâ€”next day I went with two constables to a public-house in Mare Streetâ€”I saw some men there, and amongst them the man that had given me the buns; it was the prisonerâ€”I pointed him out to the policemanâ€”I pointed out to the policeman the place where the prisoner had given me the buns, and where the woman was standing. (George Sutton, J 92, produced and proved a plan)â€”I was standing near the railway arch on the left sideâ€”the prosecutrix was standing at the corner of Kenmure Roadâ€”I am sure the prisoner is the manâ€”I had not seen him before.

JANE BASS . I am the wife of James Bass, a hawker, and live in Jacob Street, Shoreditchâ€”I sell flowers in the streetâ€”I have known the prisoner live or six years by sight, that is all; I have never spoken to himâ€”I have spoken to his wifeâ€”she sells flowers in the street, and usually stands under the railway archâ€”I generally stand at the corner of Dalston Lane, and sometimes at the corner of Kenmure Road, and sometimes close to the railway arch, opposite the Railway Tavernâ€”on the morning of 26th June I was standing outside the Railway Tavern up to about twelve o'clockâ€”I was then moved by a constableâ€”I saw the prisoner and his wife that morningâ€”she was selling flowers close to where I was, under the archâ€”when I was moved by the constable I went to the corner of Kenmure Roadâ€”about twenty minutes to four the little girl Round tree came and gave me a bag with two buns in it, and walked awayâ€”I was the only

woman selling flowers at that cornerâ€”I broke one of the buns in halves, and was going to eat itâ€”I noticed some yellow stuff come out of itâ€”it smelt nastyâ€”I went after the girl and spoke to her, and afterwards went to Hackney Police-station, and handed the bag and buns to Inspector Smithâ€”this is the bag and the pieces of buns that are left.

ARTHUR SMITH (Inspector J). I was at the station about half-past five when Bass came to me with the paper bag and two buns, one brokenâ€”from the statement she made I had the buns examined by Dr. Gouldâ€”the name of the bag was "T. Hudson, 297, Mare Street," which is a very short distance from the railway archâ€”I was at the station when the prisoner was brought in; I took the charge against him and read it over to him; he said, "It is a lie; who is to prove it?"â€”next day, Sunday, he asked me for the stuff he wanted for his sore leg, referring to the bottle of phosphorus paste and blue stone and box of zinc ointment that was found on him by the constable; thinking that he meant the zinc ointment, I bought a pennyworth and gave it to him; he said, "I use it for my leg," referring to the box of phosphorus; he might have meant all four articles.

WILLIAM KNOTT (Detective J). On 26th June this matter was handed over to me to inquire into; I traced the little girl, and on the evening of 27th, about quarter to eight, I went with her and Sergeant White lock to the Cook public-house in Mare Street; there were ten or twelve men at the bar; she pointed to the prisoner and said, "That is the man who gave me the buns "â€”I went to the prisoner and said, "We are police officers, and are going to take you into custody for attempting to kill a woman named Jane Bass by administering to her a quantity of phosphorus paste in two bath buns"â€”he said, "I never bought no buns"â€”I took hum to the station, searched him, and found on him a box of zinc ointment, some blue stone, and this little box containing phosphorus paste marked "poison"â€”when the charge was read to him he said, "It is a lie, sir; who is to prove it?"â€”when the phosphorus paste was found on him he said, "I use that for my bad leg"â€”I had it in my hand, I did not say what it wasâ€”I think I said, "Here is a bottle containing phosphorus paste"; and he said, "I use that for my bad leg."

Cross-examined by the prisoner, I came to you on the Saturday morning about half-past ten, and asked, "Do you know where a woman named Bass was standing?"â€”your wife answered, "No"â€”you said, "Why don't you speak the truth if you know anything about it?"â€”you afterwards said, "I don't know. the name, but I believe she lives near Shoreditch Church"â€”I did not charge you then, because I had no evidence against youâ€”I had not traced the little girl.

HENRY GOULD , M. R. C. S., of 102, Clarence Road, Clapton. On Saturday, the 27th, I was sent for to Mare Street Police-stationâ€”Inspector Smith handed me a bundle containing the paper bag and the broken bunsâ€”I examined the buns and found they contained a large quantity of phosphorus paste, in my opinion sufficient to destroy lifeâ€”a very small quantity would be injuriousâ€”I also examined this bottle of phosphorus pasteâ€”the quantity left in it and that in the buns would account for the differenceâ€”I believe it is sold for verminâ€”it is not recommended for bad legs; the zinc ointment would be a proper thing to useâ€”apparently a hole was made in the bottom of the bun and the
paste put into it; it was not mixed up with the bunâ€”both buns had been treated in the same way.
Cross-examined. I saw you on the Saturday morning, and you told me you used the paste for your sore leg.
GEORGE WHITELOCK (Sergeant J). The little girl pointed out to me certain points in Mare Street where the prisoner spoke to her, and where Bass was standingâ€”they were about 100 yards apart.

ALBERT PERCY (J 290). On the 20th June I was on fixed point duty in Mare Street, close to the railway archâ€”I saw Bass standing there at the opposite corner, outside the Railway Tavern; I saw the prisoner under the railway archâ€”he came to me and asked me to remove Bass, as she was stopping his customers, and taking his trade awayâ€”I refused to do it, and told him she had the same privilege as he had to stand hereâ€”he said he and his wife had stood there for a number of years, and the other had only just come, occasionally on a Saturdayâ€”next even
ing, Sunday, he came to me about seven, there were several on the op
posite side selling flowers, and he asked me to remove them, and keep them further from him, and if I did so he would make it all rightâ€”I refused.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence, denied all knowledge of the buns or of the girl.

div1.p:
GUILTY* on Second Count â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

594.
RICHARD CURTIS (48)
PLEADED GUILTY
to robbery with violence on
Robert Fisher, and stealing a bag and 22s. 9d., his property.â€”
Three Months Hard Labour.

(595).
HENRY MASON (63) and
JOHN WRIGHT** (50)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Adcock, and stealing a watch and other articles, his property; WRIGHT having been convicted of burglary at this Court in July, 1889, in the name of Robert Smith, after a previous conviction of burglary.
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.] MASONâ€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.
WRIGHTâ€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: For the case of Duke and Hitchcock, tried this day, see Kent cases.

div1.p:
596.
GEORGE HILLSON (32)
PLEADED GUILTY
to indecently assault
ing
Florence Matilda Abbley, a girl under sixteen.

p.hi:
The prisoner received a good character.â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
597.
JAMES DALGLEISH (44)
, Unlawfully committing an act of gross indocency with a male person (see page 897).

GUILTY .â€”

p.hi: For other cases tried in this Court this day, see Essex, Kent, and Surrey cases.

div1.p:
598.
ROBERT WALFORD (13),
HENRY MOODY (15),
EDWARD YOUNG ( ), and
THOMAS JENNINGS
( ), Feloniously setting fire to a stack of hay, the property of
Alfred James Voysey.
MR. DE MICHELE Prosecuted, and Mr. ERNEST BEARD Defended.
No evidence was offered against JENNINGS.
NOT GUILTY .

HENRY SHEPHERD . I am a watchman at 123, Railway Arches, Shep
herd's Bushâ€”on the night of 24th June I was in the shop of my master, who is a carpenterâ€”about twenty-five minutes past nine in the evening I heard a lot of lads running along the arches and getting over the fence, Moody and Young were two of themâ€”there were two more with themâ€”I heard Young say to one of them, "As soon as you light it halloa out"â€”I opened the door and went out after them, and caught Moodyâ€”I noticed a blaze in a field at the back of the arches belonging to Mr. Voysey; that was the next field to that from which the boys cameâ€”I told Moody I should lock him up for setting fire to the hayrickâ€”he said, "It was not me; it was one of the others; Young gave me the matches."

Cross-examined, I was in the shop when the boys came over the fenceâ€”I was about three yards from the fenceâ€”there were five boys altogetherâ€”I was inside the shop when I heard Young speakâ€”I know his voice, because he stutters badlyâ€”I had seen him before; he broke two panes of glass in the shop on Sunday nightâ€”this was on Wednesdayâ€”it is difficult to understand what he saysâ€”I don't think his words were, "As you have set it alight I shall halloa out"â€”I saw the haystack in the afternoon; it was burnt to the ground.

HENRY PERRETT (X 325). I arrested Moody and Young on the night of 29th Juneâ€”I told them it was for being concerned with Walford in setting fire to a haystackâ€”Moody said, "I own I was there, but I did not set fire to it "â€”I took Walford on the night of the 24th and charged himâ€”he said, "Hannah" (meaning Youngâ€”Hannah is his nickname) "set fire to it, while me, Jennings, and Moody, and Foxey Collins kept watch to see if anyone came "â€”the other boys were not present when he said that.

Walford's statement before the Magistrate: "I set it alight." Young's: " "We had been playing cricket, and after the game was over I was sitting on a fence, when Walford came and asked me for some matches. I did not know what he wanted them for, or I would not have given them to him; then I came away. I had nothing to do with setting fire to the rick, but heard some time after what had been done. I was not near the rick, not within two hundred yards."

MOODYâ€”
NOT GUILTY . WALFORD and YOUNGâ€”
GUILTY. Recom
mended to mercy by the JURY.â€”
Fifteen strokes each with a birch rod.

599.
ARTHUR READ EDWARDS(32)
, Idecently assaulting
Arthur Griffiths,
Frederick Greenwood,
Charles Weston,
Jersey Reynolds.

GUILTY of two slight acts of indecency .â€”
Judgment respited.

600.
JAMES HENRY CHARLES ATWILL (41)
PLEADED GUILTY
to uttering a forged order for the payment of Â£3 10s., with intent to defraud.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

601.
ROBERT MASON (68)
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences, from
George Goddard, Â£2, with intent to defraud.

GEORGE GODDARD . I am a labourer, living at 54, Spencer Streetâ€”about three p.m. on 15th July I was in bed when the prisoner, whom I have known for some time, came to my door, bringing me this note, and me said, "George, I have brought you a note; I want you to cash it for me, as I am going away on Friday morning"â€”I said, "Is the note right? "and he said, "Yes." (The advance note was for Â£4 10s., payable to Robert Mason's order, at Donald Currie's offices; Duncan, Master; and was endorsed, "Robert Mason. Please pay the bearer, Mr. George")â€”I have heard before of these advance notes for wages, which are discounted by lodging-house keepers and other peopleâ€”believing it was a valid security to me for Â£4 10s., I set off against it Â£2 10s. which he owed me, and gave him Â£2, charging him nothing for cashing the noteâ€”he asked me to come and have a drink; I said, "No, thank you"â€”I said I wanted it made payable to me, and it was endorsedâ€”next day I went to a sailors' home, and then on board the Hawarden Castleâ€”I have made inquiries; I have not tried to get any money on itâ€”when the prisoner gave it to me lie said, "You can draw the money next Wednesday"â€”he did not give it to me as a piece of waste-paper.

ALFRED BRISTOW . I am messenger at the office of Sir Donald Currie, 3 and 4, Fenchurch Street; he owns the Hawarden Castleâ€”the captain of that ship is named Duncanâ€”I know Duncan's signatureâ€”this is not his signature on the front of this document; it is his on the backâ€”our firm use no such advance note as this; we use notes like these (produced).

ARTHUR SNAPE (H 463). On 16th July I arrested the prisoner in St. George's Street East, and charged him with forging this signatureâ€”he said, "It is all right; the note is genuine "â€”I said he would have to go to the stationâ€”he said, "All right, I will go"â€”he was detained till Sergeant Glenister came in, and he was charged.

â€”GLENISTER (Sergeant H). I saw the prisoner detained at the police-station, and told him he would be charged with forging and uttering an advance note, and obtaining Â£2 by fraudâ€”he said, "All right"â€”after I had searched him, and he was charged by the inspector, he said, "I did not make any statement to the constable.

GUILTY . The prisoner then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at this Court in May, 1891.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

602.
GEORGE CHILDS (22)
, Unlawfully attempting to commit an abominable crime with a man unknown. Second Count, gross in
decency.
NOT GUILTY .

603.
CHARLES BAILEY (15) and
JAMES BROWN (15)
, Un
lawfully attempting to have carnal knowledge of
Emily Robinson, a girl aged fifteen years and nine months. Second County indecently assault
ing her.

GUILTY on Second Count . Recommended to mercy by the JURY on account of their youth.â€”
Judgment respited.

604.
BARNETT ROTH (17)
, Unlawfully attempting to carnally know
Polly Coots, a girl aged ten years. Second Count, Indecently assaulting her. MESSRS. HUTTON and ROUTH Prosecuted.

GUILTY
on Second Count. â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

605.
ISIDORE FISHER (37)
PLEADED GUILTY
to committing cer
tain offences against the Debtors' Act.
To another indictment for per
jury he pleaded NOT GUILTY.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: For the case of Robert Bradshaw, tried in Old Court this day, see Surrey Cases.

div1.p:
606.
LORENZO DEMARCO (66)
, Feloniously carnally knowing and abusing
Numacolato Tomasso, a girl under the age of thirteen.

GUILTY
of an indecent assault â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

607.
JAMES COHEN (23)
, Stealing a chain, the property of
Thomas Dwyer.

THOMAS DWYER . I am a barman, of 34, Ratton Road, Brixtonâ€”on 7th October,1890, I gave a man named Whitehead a gold chain to sell and if it was not sold for fifty-five shilling to bring it to meâ€”I saw the prisoner in the street about the same timeâ€”Whitehead showed him the chain, and said, "Will you buy it?"â€”they walked away, and I followed about six yards behind; they had some conversation, which I did not hear, and went into Roberts', a jeweller's in the Aldersgate Street, and came out, and the prisoner Walt'ers, a pawnbroker's while Whitehead stood outsideâ€”I stayed five or six minutes; the pri
soner

did not come out, and I walked over to Whitehead and spoke to him, and he went into the pawnbroker's, and came out and said some
thing to me, and I informed the police that my chain had been stolen.

Cross-examined. I know Cohen by sight, but have never spoken to himâ€”when I gave the chain to Whitehead, Cohen was not present, but he was in sight; he knew nothing of the directions I gave to Whiteheadâ€”I do a little in horseracingâ€”I cannot tell you what race was on on 7th October, but a horse named Magistrate and another named Heresy were going to run, and Magistrate was secondâ€”I sent the money to back one of them.

GEORGE WHITEHEAD . I am a skin dresser, of 39, Seward Street, Goswell Streetâ€”I have known the prisoner four or five yearsâ€”on 7th October Dwyer gave me a gold chain to sell for fifty-five shillingsâ€”he said, "Come down with me as far as Roberts's, and we will see what it weighs"â€”that is a jeweller's in Aldersgate Street; they weighed it, and asked if I would take fifty shillings for itâ€”I said, "No"â€”we came out together, and walked to Walter's, a pawnbroker's, at the corner of Aldersgate Street, and Cohen's brother came upâ€”I agreed that he should go in and pawn it if he could get fifty-five shillings on it, if not he was to bring it back to meâ€”his brother waited outside with me, but after
wards left meâ€”I waited five minutesâ€”Dwyer came and spoke to me, and I went in and spoke to the pawnbrokerâ€”I then gave information to the police.

Cross-examined. I heard of a horse named Magistrate, and another named Heresyâ€”I did not tell Cohen that Dwyer wanted the money to back a horse; I never suggested anything about racesâ€”Dwyer had had a conversation with me about a race about 1.30, and the race took place at 2.30â€”I knew that Dwyer wanted part of the money to back a horse, but I do not know how Cohen knew thatâ€”I would not accept fifty shillings for the chainâ€”I spoke to Cohen's brother that night, and said, "What makes it worse is that Cohen, my friend, was going to back Magistrate "â€”it was not Heresyâ€”I did not authorise Cohen to dispose of the chain and put the money on a horseâ€”I have known Cohen five years, but do not know where he lived.

CHARLES STEPHENS . I am assistant to Mr. Walter, a pawnbroker, of 106, Aldersgate Streetâ€”on October 7th Brook, a policeman, spoke to meâ€”before that, between two and three p.m., the prisoner came in at the Aldersgate entrance, and came up to the counter when I was serving a customer, and without saying a word he walked out into Fann Street, where there is another entrance.

Cross-examined. I was the only assistant in the shopâ€”he was not there more than two minutes, no one came in to look for him, but there was a disturbance outsideâ€”I went to the door, and Whitehead asked me if Cohen was insideâ€”I said, "No, he has passed through."

THOMAS DRAKE (140 City), On 7th October I received information and searched for the prisoner, but did not see him till July 15th about 11 p.m., he was in a refreshment house in Compton Streetâ€”I said, "Mr. Cohen, I want to speak to you in reference to a gold chain you had from a man named Whitehead, in Aldersgate Street, on 7th October last"â€”he said, "I don't know what you mean, you must have made a mistake, perhaps it was my brother"â€”I said, "Is your name James Cohen?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I told him I was a policeman, and asked him to come

with me to Moor Lane Police-stationâ€”on the way he said, "I have some recollection of the affair you speak of; I had a chain from a man with a ginger moustache somewhere about that time; I was to sell the chain and back a horse called Magistrate"â€”I said, "To whom did you sell the chain?"â€”he said, "I sold it to the bookmaker; the horse lost "â€”I said, "Are you sure of that?"â€”he said, "Yes, it ran second"â€”I said, "It is rather singular you should say that, I recollect Whitehead telling me a few days after it occurred that his friend wanted to back Magistrate with part of the money, and that Magistrate won at 6 to 1 "â€”he said, "No"â€”he was taken to the station and charged by Whitehead; he said nothingâ€”no mention was made of the horse Heresy till the following dayâ€”I produce the Racing Calendar, which shows that Magistrate won that day.

Cross-examined. I made a note of the conversation afterwardsâ€”I gave evidence at the Police-court, but did not tell the Magistrate all I have said to-dayâ€”I found there was a little more when I referred to my noteâ€”I did not mention the ginger moustache, or his saying, "I don't know what you mean; you must have made a mistake"â€”on the 17th I went into the witness-box againâ€”my evidence was read over, and I produced the Racing Calendar, but I gave no evidenceâ€”I did not think it material to correct my former evidenceâ€”he said he sold the chain to the bookmaker, but nothing was said about the horseâ€”he did not say he had backed a horse in Magistrate's raceâ€”he said, "I backed the horse Magistrate, which ran and lost"â€”I said, "It is singular you should say that, because Whitehead told me he saw your brother a few days afterwards who said the horse ran and won"â€”I stated that at the Police-courtâ€”Cohen called a witness at the Police-courtâ€”I heard Whitehead mention the brother this morningâ€”I have not had a word of conversation with Whitehead about the case.

The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "At the time the detective arrested me I was so confused with having a false accusation made against me my mind was so upset I could not call to mind the name of the horse I did back, but the horse was mentioned by Mr. Whitehead. He said, 'Mr. Cohen, I want you to sell this gold chain for fifty shillings, and put the money on Heresy in Magistrate's race,' which I did do. I was in Walter's about five o'clock, I had a diamond ring I was going to pledge, but as he was busy I came out."

FREDERICK LESTER . I live at 26, Freda Street, Essex Road, Islington, and am a dealer in jewelleryâ€”in October, 1890, I was with Cohen in Goswell Road; I have known his family twenty yearsâ€”Whitehead came up to me, and said, "I have got a gold chain here, and I want you to sell it and back a horse called Heresy with the money, Â£2 10s. "â€”the race was going to be run the same day, and this was at twelve or half-past twelveâ€”I did not see Dwyer thereâ€”lots of jewellery business is done in the streetsâ€”they went to Roberts's, and I followed them as far as Fann Street, and then I went into a public-house, and Whitehead said, "Come on, I am going to sell this chain and back Heresy at the Bouverie Club with the money"â€”that was in Bouverie Streetâ€”I did not go in because I am not a memberâ€”he came out and said, "I have sold the chain for Â£2 10s.; what will you have on Heresy?"â€”I said, "Eight shillings," and he put on eight shillings for me alsoâ€”I am certain Heresy did not win, because I lost
the eight shillings, and I only had ten shillingsâ€”I was going to put that on, but Whitehead and Cohen were rushing about, and I thought they knew something good.

Cross-examined. I distinctly heard him tell Whitehead to sell the chain for Â£2 10s.; I was only a few yards offâ€”I did not hear of any other horseâ€”I know Magistrate won, but I never heard of him till after he won.
Re-examined. Magistrate got six to one, and Heresy six and a half to one.

By the JURY. I believe my eight shillings was paid to a bookmaker named Robinsonâ€”Cohen went back into the club to put on my eight shillings added to the fifty shillingsâ€”that was done inside the clubâ€”I am sure he did it, by his anxious mannerâ€”I believe the chain was sold to the bookmaker.

GUILTY â€”
Two Months' Hard Labour,

608.
LOUIS BRACE (29) and
LOUIS KENDAL (24)
, Unlawfully attempting to commit an unnatural offence.
NOT GUILTY .

609.
HARRY TAPLEY,
Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Frederick Bandy, and stealing two coats and 1s. 6d., his property.

ELIZABETH BANDY . I am the wife of Frederick Bandy, of 300, Mile End Roadâ€”on 14th June I went to bed with my husband about 1.30 a.m., he having seen the house securedâ€”I was awake about 3.30, and saw a man in our room with his back towards me, facing the chest of drawersâ€”directly I moved the bedclothes he went out of the room, but came in again in a minute or two; I saw his face thenâ€”it was the prisoner; I have no doubt about him whateverâ€”he stood with his hand on the bedstead; I was very frightened, thinking he might have a revol
ver, and was afraid to wake my husbandâ€”he went out, and came back a third time, and stood with his right hand on the door, and when I saw his hands were free I awoke my husbandâ€”I could not speak; but from the action I gave, he went downstairsâ€”I saw the prisoner plainly both times, and have no doubt about him; I shall never forget his face as long as I live.

Cross-examined. This was 3.30 a.m.; the Venetian blinds were down, but the curtains were openâ€”it was as light as it is nowâ€”I said before the Magistrate that my eyes were not wide openâ€”the man's hair was as red as the prisoner'sâ€”I told the police his hair was inclined to be carrotty, more of a rednessâ€”there were from eight to twelve men present when I identified him, two of whom had red hair, the prisoner and anotherâ€”that was a week afterwards.
Re-examined. I had not the slightest difficulty in picking him outâ€”I recognised him at once.

FREDERICK BANDY . I am an oil and colourman of 300, Mile End Roadâ€”on 14th June, about 3.30 a.m. my wife awoke meâ€”it was lightâ€”I heard a noise, ran to the top of the stairs on the landing, and saw one man, and heard more running downstairsâ€”I went back into the next bedroom, opened the window, and called "Police," and saw three men run down the yard towards Ely Placeâ€”I cannot describe either of themâ€”I had seen the house securely fastened the night beforeâ€”I went back to my

bedroom, put my head out at the window, saw two policemen, and called themâ€”I then went down and found the woodwork of the shop-parlour window forced away, the shutters forced, the bolt broken, and the catch cut awayâ€”I missed the articles mentioned, and several others since and some money.
PATRICK KELLY (H 300). On 14th June, about 3.45 a.m., I was on duty in Hartford Street, and saw the prisoner to the best of my belief, and two others.

WILLIAM GOLDING (Police Sergeant K). I took the prisoner on 22nd June, shortly before 10 a.m., in the Mile End Road, and took him to Arbour Square Station, where he was placed with others, some of whom were very fair menâ€”Mrs. Bandy came in and identified him; she was not long about it, but she looked at them allâ€”he gave his address at 1, Medway Road, which is nearly half a mile from 300, Mile End Roadâ€”I walked it the other day in fourteen minutes.

Cross-examined. I did my best in getting men with as near the same shade of hair, from the passers-by, but I could not get any with hair like that; his is fiery redâ€”there were eight of them, and one had hair very nearly like thatâ€”I had not taken the prisoner in custody the previous Saturday, but I saw him in custody, and he was taken to Bow Stationâ€”the inspector had received a description of the man in the woman's roomâ€”he was taken before Inspector Dwyer, and allowed to goâ€”he gave his right name and address on the Saturdayâ€”he said he knew nothing about it; he could prove where he wasâ€”he asked me to go to his house and inquire of his parentsâ€”they are very respectable peopleâ€”I went on the Monday and saw his motherâ€”the prisoner has never been charged with any offence that I know of.
Re-examined. I did not know him till the Saturdayâ€”I have made inquiries about himâ€”he told me he worked on and off at the docks, but he did not say which.

OCTAVTUS TAPLEY . I live at 1, Medway Road, Bethnal Green, and am buyer for Mr. Keeler, of Whitechapel Roadâ€”I have a large family, and the prisoner is one of themâ€”he was living at home in Juneâ€”he was assistant to a pawnbroker at Nottingham, but left there at the beginning of the yearâ€”I was looking out for something better for him, and mean
while he was employed at the Royal Albert Docksâ€”there is no truth in the suggestion of the police that he has ever been in troubleâ€”I have one son who got into difficultiesâ€”on Saturday night, 13th June, I got home about ten minutes to twelveâ€”I have a latchkey; nobody else in the house has oneâ€”I let myself in, and one of my sons, Percy, came in about two minutes after meâ€”it is my custom to go round and see if all my family are safe at homeâ€”I went into the prisoner's room, and found him in bed and asleep with others of my familyâ€”after Percy came in I bolted the door with two 9-inch bolts, and went to bedâ€”there is a back door, but that leads nowhere, you cannot get away thereâ€”on Sunday morning I came down at 8.30â€”the prisoner was not upâ€”I un
fastened the door; it was in the same condition as when I went to bedâ€”the prisoner came down to breakfast at 9.30â€”when the police came to me I first heard that he was charged with burglary; I said that they had made a mistake, he was in bed.
Cross-examined. I was at the Police-court at the hearing, but was not

calledâ€”the prisoner was last in employment about eight months agoâ€”11.30 was his latest time for coming inâ€”lie was never in the streets as late as one o'clock; he has never been seen in the streets by the police as late as one o'clockâ€”he was in Nottingham seven or eight monthsâ€”he was also employed at Wisbech about eighteen months, and left on 20th April, 1890â€”his two younger brothers, Percy and Charles, were sleeping in the room with himâ€”their ages are sixteen and twelveâ€”he never stayed out late at night unless I let him inâ€”I am more than a quarter of an hour's walk from 300, Mile End Road, unless I walk very quickâ€”I have never heard any complaint against the prisoner, or of his having been fined, or of disorderly conduct.
Re-examined. This son has never given me any trouble.

ELIZABETH TAPLEY . I am the wife of the last witness, and the prisoner's motherâ€”I have a son who has been in trouble, but the prisoner has always been thoroughly respectableâ€”on Saturday night, June 13th, he came in about 9.30, and only went out again into the front garden talk
ing to the neighboursâ€”he was in bed at elevenâ€”I was in my bedroom when my husband came in at 11.50, but not in bedâ€”I had left the door unlatched for him to come inâ€”he sees that the lamps are all out, and the children all inâ€”he, locks the front door, and nobody can get in or out at the back doorâ€”I went down at 9.30 a.m. and had breakfast with the prisoner.

Cross-examined. This was Sunday night, and my attention was called to it because a neighbour of ours diedâ€”the prisoner comes home at 11.30 at the latest, perhaps twelve on Saturday nights if he has been to any place of amusement, and then we always let him in.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: DOUGLAS SWIFT (K 387). I arrested the prisoner on June 20thâ€”I have known him about four yearsâ€”I have seen him as late as one a.m., some mornings at 1.5â€”I called his attention to the rowdyism opposite the Plough, Mile End Roadâ€”his associates are convicted thievesâ€”his brother Walter has been out of prison ten days for a watch robbery.

Cross-examined. I did not know him when he was at Nottinghamâ€”I have not been to Wisbech to ascertain his character thereâ€”I do not suggest that he has been charged with or convicted of any offenceâ€”I have lost sight of him for a short period.

p.hi: Witnesses called by request of the Jury.

div1.p: CHAKLES TAPLEY . I live at home with my fatherâ€”the prisoner is my brother; he was living at home last month, and slept in the same room with meâ€”I remember his being taken upâ€”on the Sunday week before that he was in bed before meâ€”I went to bed at half-past eleven and slept in another bed; I went to sleep; I awoke at four a.m., and the prisoner was then in bedâ€”I know the time, because my brother Harry asked me to get him a drink of water, and I went into the kitchen to get it; it was then four o'clockâ€”I went to bed again, and awoke about eight, and went down and saw my brother at breakfast.

PERCY TAPLEY . I live with my father, mother, and brothersâ€”on the Saturday night before the prisoner was taken in custody I came home about twelve o'clockâ€”my father let me in; I went into the kitchen and had my supper and went to bedâ€”the prisoner and the last witness slept in the same room with meâ€”the prisoner was in bed and asleep when I

went to bed; I did not sleep in the same bed with him, I slept with my little brotherâ€”I awoke about 9.30 next morning; I never woke in the night; my brother was not thereâ€”I dressed and went down, and found them down thereâ€”Harry could not have gone out during the night without disturbing me.
NOT GUILTY .

610.
MICHAEL BUCHANAN (35)
, Robbery with violence on
Thomas Sparks, and stealing Â£12, his money.

THOMAS SPARKS . I am a drover, of 129, George's Road, Hollowayâ€”on 9th May, between 8.30 and 9, I was in Red lion Street, Clerkenwell, and was knocked down by the prisoner and another person, who has been convicted and is doing twelve months' hard labour (See Reg. v. Madden, page 843.) I cannot swear to the prisoner, because it was a dark placeâ€”I lost Â£12 from my pocket-book, which I saw safe in the middle of the day, and I put it back in my pocket.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. One of the men knelt on my chest; they were both over me, and both pretty near my chestâ€”I seized one and held himâ€”I got my bag back, but it was Â£3 10s. short.

JOHN WILSON . I live at 12, Benjamin Street, Clerkenwellâ€”on 9th May, a little before nine p.m., I was in Red Lion Street, Clerkenwell, and saw the prisoner and Madden knock Sparks down; the prisoner knelt on his chest, while Madden rifled his pocketsâ€”Sparks laid hold of Madden, and the prisoner tried to rescue himâ€”a constable came up, and the prisoner made off, and I saw no more of him till he was in custody.

Cross-examined. I was nearer to Sparks than I am to you when he was being robbed; I was half a yard from himâ€”it took place very quicklyâ€”the prisoner was trying to pull Madden from Sparks, but could not.

ALFRED HILL . I live at 22, White Horse Alley, Clerkenwellâ€”on 9th May I was in Red Lion Street, and saw Sparks passing through Eagle Court; the prisoner and Madden knocked him down, and the prisoner knelt on his chest while Madden took a bag from himâ€”it was dark, but I could see what they were doingâ€”a gentleman fetched a policeman.

Cross-examined. Wilson was about the same distance from Sparks as I wasâ€”neither of us did anythingâ€”Sparks had got hold of Madden, and the prisoner was trying to get him away, but could not, and went away himself.

SAMUEL WATERMAN (G 241). On June 20th I saw the prisoner at the corner of St. John Streetâ€”he walked away, and then commenced to runâ€”I was in plain clothesâ€”he went up St. John Streetâ€”I beckoned to an officer, who went over, and when the prisoner saw that, he stopped, and I took him in custodyâ€”he said, "All right, I own I was there, but I took no part in it"â€”I took him to the station, and told him he would be charged, with another person now doing twelve months, with stealing Â£12 from the person.
Cross-examined, I said, "Where have you been?"â€”he said, "I have been working at Sevenoaks. "
By the COURT.Â£8 was found on Madden, which was returned to Sparks.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I plead guilty to being there in Madden's company, but I never had any idea of what was going to occur between him and Sparks. Sparks sent me to call Madden out
to have a glass of beer, and when I came hack Sparks was holding on to Madden, and said he had got his bag of money. "

GUILTY .â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction at this Court of robbery with violence on 13th December, 1886â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour,

611.
FREDERICK PREST (26) and
THOMAS NEARY (32)
, Steal
ing eight gallons of gin, four gallons of whisky, and four gallons of port, the property of
William Barker, the master of Prest.

PHILIP GEORGE CHEVALIER . I am manager to William Barker and Sons, wine and spirit merchants, 48, Bishopsgate Street Withoutâ€”we have three branches, an ordinary public-house, a family wine merchant's business, and a wholesale wine departmentâ€”Prest has been in our whole
sale department about four and a half yearsâ€”on Tuesday, 30th June, he was mainly employed in filling casks; it was also his duty, when it became necessary, to fill jars of persons coming to have orders executed in that wayâ€”I think that until recently the filling of jars had been his exclusive employment, I think the foreman will speak more about thatâ€”various public-houses in the metropolis deal with us as wholesale wine and spirit merchantsâ€”this is one of the books kept in our wholesale department as a record of all orders taken and executedâ€”a customer at the wholesale department would go first to the order counter and give his order, the quantity and quality of which the clerk would enter on this counterfoilâ€”then he would enter the quantity and quality on the black ticket, which he would give to the customer, who would take it to and leave it with the servant in charge of the jar-filling departmentâ€”the customer would return to the order counter and receive from the clerk a red ticket on which, in the meantime, the clerk had filled the particulars of quantity and quality, an invoice showing the price, and the customer's permitâ€”the customer would take them to the cashier's desk; the entry would be entered in the day journal; the customer would pay the money; the clerk would initial the back of the invoice to indicate that the order had been paid and enteredâ€”then the customer would take the red ticket to the servant to whom he had given the black ticket, and who, in the meantime, would have executed the order, pasted the black ticket on the jar, and sealed it upâ€”the man would compare the black and red tickets, and give the red ticket back to the customer, who would then take the jar awayâ€”I have seen Neary several timesâ€”I don't know that he came from the Duke of Clarenceâ€”I saw him on 30th June bringing in empty jarsâ€”I saw him during the whole time he was proceeding with his order, going from one counter to the otherâ€”I saw him taking one jar outside.

Cross-examined by MR. ROOTH. We conduct business on a large scale and receive a great many orders; we do not have a great many orders like this; we chiefly have travellers' and letter ordersâ€”we receive a consider
able number of orders; Prest is one of the men who would have to carry

them outâ€”the customer and the man who fills the jars come together some
timesâ€”the customer hands the order to one of the warehousemen, who has to execute itâ€”we are not free from mistakesâ€”Mitchell is in our employment; I am not aware that he made a mistake with regard to Nearyâ€”my attention was not called to the fact that Mitchell poured out a smaller quantity than was on the orderâ€”I did not see how these jars were filledâ€”we have no option as to the size of a jar when a man brings his own jarâ€”I was present when the constable came backâ€”Abbott said to Prest, "Before we measure this, what is it?"â€”Prest said, "There are four gallons in each, for what I have the order for"â€”that was what was in the jarsâ€”Abbott said, "What are they?" and he replied, "Two four gallons of gin, four of whisky, four of port."

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. There are three men in the room where the jars are filledâ€”Prest was in that roomâ€”there is a bar that lifts up and down, at which a customer would stand as a ruleâ€”we do not strictly enforce the rule of not allowing customers to go inside; the bar is in
tended for people to stand atâ€”I could not say if I saw Neary inside the bar; I don't think I didâ€”I saw him backwards and forwardsâ€”the jars would be filled inside by Prest or any of the other warehousemen, and would be carried outsideâ€”the purchaser would receive the jars at the bar, and take them to the cartâ€”he would take no part in filling them.

Re-examined, If we supply a jar at a customer's request we supply a two-gallon jar for a two-gallon order, and a four-gallon jar for a four-gallon orderâ€”very often customers bring their own bottles or jarsâ€”there is no practice, custom, or rule as to what sized bottle or jar he brings.

ERNEST JOSIAH NASH . I am a clerk in "William Barker and Sons' em
ploymentâ€”I receive orders from customersâ€”I am supplied with these booksâ€”Smith is the warehouse foremanâ€”he is away between two and three on Tuesdays at our Broad Street Branch, and on Fridays he is away from eleven to one on other dutiesâ€”on Tuesday, 30th June, he was awayâ€”I have known Neary for about six months as a customer coming once or twice a week; he very often came on Tuesdays and Fridaysâ€”on Tuesday, 30th June, he came between two and threeâ€”I was sitting aloneâ€”he said, "Will you take my order, Mr. Nash?"â€”he gave me the order in the name of James, the name of an old customer of ours at the Duke of Clarenceâ€”he always gave the name of Jamesâ€”he said, "Two gallons of old torn," meaning unsweetened ginâ€”I wrote it down, and said, "Thirty-three underâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”that was the strength which he was in the habit of buying; I knew it quite wellâ€”he said, "Two gallons of dry gin," or unsweetenedâ€”I said, "Thirty-three under"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”that was the usual strength of the dry ginâ€”he said, "Two gallons of Irish whisky"â€”I said, "Twenty-five under?" he said, "Yes" that is the cheapest, and his usual class of goodsâ€”he said, "Two gallons of port"â€”I said, "S. R. "; that is our trade sign for our cheapest port, "Spanish Bed," a Tarragona wine at 5s. per gallonâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I entered those particulars on the counterfoils, and filled up these four black tickets, tore them out of the book, and gave them to him for one to be stuck on each jar; he had brought four jars with himâ€”he took the tickets into the warehouseâ€”the jars had the tickets in my writing on them at Guildhallâ€”one has since

got rubbed offâ€”after the prisoner had taken the tickets and the jars into the warehouse, the junior clerk, Todd, came in, and he made out these red ticketsâ€”Todd has gone for his holiday; these tickets are in his writingâ€”they are similar to the entry in my writing on the counter-foils.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. When Smith is away we are all supposed to keep our eyes about us to see that things go right; no one is deputed to specially look outâ€”there is opposite to my office another office, with five or six clerksâ€”there are ten or twelve people about when the manager is away, but they cannot see very well what is going onâ€”they are supposed to keep a look out when the manager is awayâ€”only one was in the warehouse on this occasion; that was Prestâ€”I cannot say if anybody was bottle-washing at the tub; there would be as a ruleâ€”I have noticed by referring back to his orders that Neary has generally come on Tuesdays and Fridaysâ€”it is not unusual for a man to come always on the same day.

Re-examined. There are three clerks in my department, the order department; it is quite separate from the warehouse, into which I do not go unless I have something special to say to the foreman; it is on the same floor as my officeâ€”I cannot see what goes on in the warehouseâ€”the ledger-keeper's office is an enclosed place on the same floor, there are about half-a-dozen clerks there; they have nothing to do with the warehouseâ€”if they leave off their work and take the trouble to look, they can see what goes on in the warehouse; but if they had no reason to be suspicious they would take no noticeâ€”as a rule, three men are employed in the warehouse filling the bottlesâ€”Smith is foreman of the filling and the casks; he is overlooker in the bottle departmentâ€”when he is away on Tuesday and Friday no one takes his place as overlooker of the warehouse.

ARTHUR JOLLY . I am a clerk to the prosecutorsâ€”on 30th June I acted as cashier during the cashier's absenceâ€”between two and three, I think, Neary came to me with this customer's permit, these four red tickets and the invoice corresponding with them, and representing a total value of Â£3 6s. 10d. for two gallons of dry gin, two of old torn, two of whisky, and two of portâ€”he paid me Â£3 6s. 10d.; I receipted the invoice and handed it with the red tickets and the permit to him, and he went away in the direction of the warehouse.

CHARLES SMITH . I am foreman of this warehouseâ€”I have been with Messrs. Barker between seven and eight yearsâ€”Prest has been with them between four and five years, I should say, and during that time he has been under me as warehouseman, filling jars and casksâ€”at first he was in the cellar, and then he came into the warehouse to fill jars, and then he filled casks, which require more experienceâ€”it does not take all a man's time to fill casks; he fills jars as wellâ€”on Tuesday, between two and three, I always go to our Broad Street establishment to turn over the wines and spirits there; and on Fridays, from eleven to one, I am absent from the warehouseâ€”it is our dip dayâ€”it is known to all the men in the warehouse that I am absent for those hoursâ€”I take a man with me to turn over on Friday, and to Broad Street on Tuesday, so that sometimes only one man is left in the warehouse, and that one has always been Prest for the last two or three yearsâ€”he has never had to turn over dipâ€”he would always be the one left in the warehouse on
