Tuesday, because I took him to be a respectable man and had great con
fidence in him, and left him in chargeâ€”sometimes a man was left with him; on this particular Tuesday he was aloneâ€”a four gallon jar weighs about 26 lb. empty, 60 lb. full, and about 44 lb. if it contains two gallonsâ€”it does not require a vast amount of intelligence for a man to dis
tinguish between a full and half-full one; he would know the difference if he were carrying one in one hand and one in the otherâ€”when I came back on the 30th I saw Neary coming out of our warehouse with a four gallon jar in his handâ€”a costermonger's, barrow was standing outside; I saw another jar on the kerb by the side of the barrow, and I believe a third one was on the barrow partly covered with a sackâ€”I saw him lift the one he was carrying and the one on the kerb on to the barrow and cover them overâ€”I believe another man was with him who helped him cover themâ€”I saw them move offâ€”afterwards they were brought back; as I was walking into the warehouse Mr. Barker met me with the permit, and afterwards the prisoners were brought in; I had the jars measured in the presence of Mr. Barker, my manager, and myself; they contained four gallons of dry gin, four gallons of old torn, four gallons of whisky, and four gallons of portâ€”I tested the quality, and found that the dry gin and the old torn were 17 under proof instead of 33, the whisky was 10 over proof instead of 25 under, and the port wine was either 10s. 8d. or 13s. a gallon instead of 5s.; it was more than twice as goodâ€”our warehouseman would fill a four-gallon jar with a four-gallon copper measure, and a two-gallon jar with a two-gallon copper measure.

Cross-examined by MR. ROOTH. I went after Prest's character when he came four or five years agoâ€”Mr. Newton, of Cannon Street, wine merchant, with whom he had been, would not give me a character; he said he had no fault to find with him, and I was pressed for a man, so I took him onâ€”he has gone on rising in our firm, and now he is in a very responsible position; I trusted himâ€”no mistake was made with Mitchell that I am aware of; Aldred was not in our employment.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. The difference of weight between four and two gallons would be 16 lb.; it would not be so discernible if you carried the two gallons two or three days after carrying the four gallons, as if you carried them one in one hand and one in the otherâ€”the man who was with Neary, and assisted him in putting the jars into the cart, was charged before the Magistrate and dischargedâ€”I am sure no one was with Prest in the warehouse when I went away; one man went with me, and the other was engaged packing claret in the cellar underneath the warehouseâ€”when I left Prest was engaged in. filling a hogshead which was not filled when I came backâ€”clerks and people are passing by the barrier into the warehouse.

ARTHUR ERNEST MORRIS . I am one of six clerks in Mr. Chevalier's office, the ledger departmentâ€”our office is surrounded by glass, so that I can see into the warehouse; there are three large panes of glass in front of meâ€”that is the only window from which you can see into the warehouseâ€”I received special instructions from my employer to keep a watch on Prest, to see how he transacted his businessâ€”I had received instructions to watch him and Neary on Friday, 26th June, and on that day I saw Neary there between twelve and one, and I saw Prest go down to the cellar steps with two two-gallon cans; he brought them up

and emptied the contents of one into a four-gallon jar, and the other he placed on the foreman's desk, facing my windowâ€”he went away, and I could hear the washing of a can; he went to another part of the ware-house, and turned the contents of that two-gallon can into another four-gallon jarâ€”he came back, took the two-gallon can which contained port off the foreman's desk, and poured the contents into the port jar, which already contained two gallons, making four in allâ€”I saw nothing else that day; I reported what I had seen to my employersâ€”I was instructed to keep watch again on Tuesday, 30thâ€”I then, between two and three saw Prest place four four-gallon jars in a row in the warehouse, and then turn the contents of a two-gallon can over into those four jars eight times, that would make sixteen gallonsâ€”I saw nothing of Nearyâ€”I gave information to Mr. Barker and Mr. Chevalier, as the result of which the prisoners were brought back three or four minutes afterwardsâ€”I saw the foreman measure out the jars, and test the strengthâ€”I heard him say the strengths were considerably overâ€”I am quite sure that I saw Prest use a two-gallon measure.

Cross-examined by MR. ROOTH. Prest's business is pouring out these thingsâ€”the whole of this was done in a most open mannerâ€”no customers were thereâ€”our office is in the corner of the warehouse, and you can see right into itâ€”anyone looking through the window could see everything going on.
Re-examined. I should not look through the window unless I were instructed to do so.

PHILIP GEORGE CHEVALIER (Re-examined). Gin and old torn seventeen underproof would be 10s. 8d. a gallon; whisky ten overproof would be 15s. 7d.; the port I estimated to be 13s. a gallon, so that the total value of the goods Neary was taking away was Â£9 19s. 8d., instead of the Â£3 6s. 10d. that he had paid, a difference of Â£6 12s. 10d.

THOMAS ABBOTT (Detective Sergeant City). About 2.30 on 30th June I saw Neary and Baker going from Messrs. Barker's with a trolly containing some jarsâ€”I had received instructionsâ€”I stopped them, and told them I was a police officer, and asked them what they had in the jarsâ€”Neary said, "Two gallons in each," producing the invoice for goods worth Â£3 6s. 10d., and the permitâ€”I said, "I have reason to believe there is some mistake here; you will have to come back with me, and let me measure it"â€”Neary replied, "If I have got more than my measure I don't know it"â€”I conveyed them back to the warehouse; the jars were taken into itâ€”I said to Prest, "I am a police-officer; before we measure the contents of these jars how much is there in them?"â€”he replied, "Four gallons in each; what I had the order for "â€”I said, "Of what?'â€”he said, "Two four gallons of gin in each jar, four gallons of whisky, and four gallons of port"â€”he said he had filled them with one canâ€”we measured the contents of the jars, and found they each contained four gallonsâ€”the foreman tested them as wellâ€”the prisoners were given in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I had been there altogether seventeen or eighteen daysâ€”I had seen Neary and Baker there beforeâ€”the jars were sealed.

WILLIAM WHITEHEAD (City Detective). I was with Abbottâ€”I accom
panied the prisoners to the stationâ€”when they were charged they
made no replyâ€”Baker was discharged by the Magistrate, as there was no evidence against him.

CHARLES SMITH (Re-examined). The instrument for testing spirits is Sykes's hydrometerâ€”it is well known in the tradeâ€”every publican ought to keep one, as the law is very stringent with regard to not selling under a certain proof; the difference in value is very considerable.

JAMES BLUMSON . I keep the Duke of Clarence at Hackneyâ€”Neary has been my potman for the last eighteen months; he assists in the bar when he is wantedâ€”I always found him very straightforward and honestâ€”he has taken money over the bar; I have had no reason to complain of him.

Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. These goods were ordered for meâ€”Neary was instructed to order two gallons of gin 33 under proof at 8s. 9d., two gallons of old torn at 8s. 9d., two gallons of whisky, and two gallons of the cheapest port; that was the ordinary order than I was in the habit of givingâ€”if he had arrived safely at my public-house with the four jars, he would have taken them into the spirit room and emptied themâ€”if I had been at home I should have been thereâ€”we always buy spirit of the breaking down strengthâ€”we have to take care we don't buy it under a certain strength, because we are liable to prosecutionâ€”I keep a hydrometer, but I should not test spirit, I bought from Barker, because I should believe in the qualityâ€”I should know the difference between 5s. and 13s. portâ€”I should take Barker's word for the strength of the spiritâ€”if I measured it and found 1 had more than I ordered I should send to Barker'sâ€”I should find out if I had got whisky ten over proof, the customers would find it out; it would want well watering, which would increase the quantity very greatlyâ€”four gallons of whisky ten over proof when watered down to its proper strength would come to five or just over five gallons.

Re-examined. If I found out such a mistake I should communicate to Barkerâ€”once before Neary told me he brought back a gallon too little by mistake, and he went back and got the gallon, and they apologisedâ€”I am Neary's brother-in-law.

By the JURY. I believe Neary generally took four-gallon jarsâ€”I have two-gallon jars, but they might have cordials or other things in them, and so as a rule he took gallon jars; if he wanted two gallons he would take a two-gallon jar if one was empty, but if not he would take a four-gallon jarâ€”I believe I ordered two gallons of port on the Fridayâ€”I did not order it myself.
THOMAS ABBOTT (Re-examined by the JURY). I began watching on the 10th and finished on the 30th, but I was not there on the 26th; another officer took my place.
NOT GUILTY .

612.
JOHN WALL and
WILLIAM SIDLEY,
Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Alfred Lazarus and stealing thirty-two pairs of boots, his goods, to which WALL
PLEADED GUILTY .

CHARLES LAZENBURY . I live at 5, Teesdale Street, Hackney Roadâ€”on Tuesday night, 7th July, I was in that street and saw three men walking up and down till about 9.45, and then I saw Sidley lift Wall and another

man over the fence into the wood-yard, and then he walked up and down and whistledâ€”I waited, and when a policeman came up I informed him of what I had seenâ€”the police arrested Sidley, who said he was waiting for a woman at nine o'clockâ€”it was then about 10.30â€”I went into the yard with the police; they found Wall there hiding behind some timber.

Cross-examined. Sidley gave the other men a leg-up, and then walked up and down the wood-yard about twenty yardsâ€”I was about fifteen feet away, standing outside the wood-yard watching against the gateâ€”Sidley saw me watching; I don't suppose he noticed me there, he saw me there.

GEORGE WARNER (J 33). About 10.30 p.m. on 7th July I was in Teesdale Road; Lazenbury told me somethingâ€”I went into the wood-yard adjoining Lazarus's premises, and saw Wall thereâ€”I did not see Sidley there.

FREDERICK WISDOM (J 147). On the evening of 7th July Lazenbury spoke to me, and I went into the wood-yard; I found a chisel where Wall was concealedâ€”I saw Sidley standing beside the yard, and asked him what he was doing thereâ€”he said, "I am waiting for a woman who promised to meet me at nine o'clock"â€”it was then about 10.30â€”the following morning I went into the yard where Wall was found, and found two lots of boots, one lot done up in an apron, and one lot in a sack.
Cross-examined. Sidley was standing outsideâ€”he was not under the influence of drink; I took no notice if he smelt of drink.

ALFRED LAZARUS . I am a shoemaker, of 410, Hackney Roadâ€”the timber-yard adjoins my premisesâ€”about eight p.m. on July 7th I saw my premises safeâ€”in the morning I missed thirty-two pairs of boots, value about Â£15â€”these are they.
ARTHUR SHARP (J 522). I was with Wisdom, and took Sidley into custody.

ROBERT STEMP (Inspector J). I examined the premisesâ€”access was gained by climbing over some gates, seven or eight feet high, into a timber-yard, and then getting over a large heap of timber into a closet, passing their hand through a piece of paper pasted over a broken pane of glass, and opening a window.

Cross-examined. There is only one timber-yard, it is a very large one, and there is great confusion of timberâ€”the gates of the yard are closed at night, and then you can only get in by climbing over the gatesâ€”when I saw them it was ten or eleven.

SIDLEYâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

WALL then
PLEADED GUILTY**â€ to a conviction of felony in February, 1887.â€”
Twenty Months' Hard Labour.

613.
MARY SANDSTREAM (35)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully attempting to drown herself.

p.hi:
She had attempted suicide a week previously, but was discharged by the Magistrate on her promise not to repeat the offence.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
614.
JOHN HARRIS,
Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences from
William Howard two postal orders for 10&. and 2s. 6d.; and other postal orders and money from
Sidney Needes and
James Henry Kemsley, with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM HOWARD . I live at 5, Chapel Road, Stamford Hill, and am a ratcatcherâ€”on 23rd January I saw this advertisement in the Bazaar, Exchange and Mart. (This advertised ferrets for sale; applications to be made to J. Harris, 350, High Street, Stratford)â€”in consequence of that I wrote the same day to J. Harris at that address, enclosing postal orders for 2s. and 10s. 6d.â€”I received no acknowledgment of the money, nor any answer, and on Wednesday, 28th February, I went to 350, High Street, Stratford, and found it was a beer-shopâ€”I saw the prisoner in another compartment there; directly he came into the house he made brag that he had sold seventy ferrets, and had four more to dispose of; then a post
man came in with some letters; the prisoner received three or four of them at the bar; the first letter he opened he read and put in his left breast pocket, and the next one he turned all manner of colours as he read itâ€”I came out of my compartment, and when he saw that he ran away; I had not said anything to him.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not touch you in the public-house, nor speak to youâ€”I had never seen you beforeâ€”I did not take the numbers of the orders.

JAMES HENRY KEMSLEY . I am a butcher, of 20, High Street, Sitting-bourneâ€”I saw an advertisement similar to this in the Bazaar, Exchange and Mart, in consequence of which I sent a P.O. for five shillings to J. Harris, at 350, High Street, Stratfordâ€”I did not receive any reply or ferrets.

SIDNEY NEEDES . I am a steward, of the North-West Hospital, Hampsteadâ€”I saw an advertisement similar to this in the Bazaar, Exchange and Mart in January, and in consequence I sent to 350, High Street, Stratford, a postal order for five shillings and sixpenceâ€”I received an acknowledgment a day or two afterwards; I have destroyed it; it regretted he had not answered my letter before, as he had so many advertisements to answer, and said that he should be going into the country in a day or two, and then he would forward the ferrets onâ€”I never heard from him againâ€”I never received any ferrets.

JAMES HENRY ARGENT . I keep a beerhouse at 350, High Street, Stratfordâ€”I know the prisoner by his coming in thereâ€”in January this year he asked me if I would take in one or two letters for himâ€”he said his name was Harrisâ€”I consentedâ€”some two or three dozen letters came for him, some in the name of Harris, and some John Harrisâ€”two days after he called, I handed them to him; two were registeredâ€”the Wed
nesday evening when Howard was there was the second time the prisoner had come for lettersâ€”the prisoner was not a regular customer; he had only come in about three timesâ€”he ran out of the house when Howard was there, and did not come back againâ€”letters continued to come for him; about 195 came; I gave them to the police, finding he did not come.
Cross-examined. You were in the house before Howard came on the Wednesdayâ€”you were there ten or fifteen minutesâ€”you left one bar and

came into another one, stopped there some time and went outâ€”I cannot say if you ran out hastily; you walked outâ€”you received two or three letters from the postmanâ€”I kept the letters that came for you locked up in a box; nobody had access to itâ€”the second time you came you said you expected some letters complaining that the persons had not received their ferretsâ€”you asked me if I had any letters for you, and I said there were none.

FREDERICK FORTH (Detective Sergeant). I received information, and on 27th February Argent handed me 197 letters, twenty-two postcards, and three telegramsâ€”a warrant was obtained against the prisoner; after that he was searched for in the usual way till 29th June, when I arrested him at Tunbridge Wellsâ€”I brought him to Stratford, and read the warrant to him; it charged him with the larceny of these moneysâ€”he said, "I did not receive all the orders; some I destroyed"â€”I asked his nameâ€”he said, "John Harris"â€”afterwards he said, "My right name is Gardiner."

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, said he had some ferrets which he sent off; that he did not say in the advertisement how many he had; and that he had not received all the letters.

div1.p:
GUILTY *â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

615.
BELAL MABROOC,
Feloniously wounding
Feruz Muftar, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

The prisoner stated, in the hearing of the JURY, that he was
GUILTY of unlawfully wounding, and the JURY
returned that verdict. â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.

616.
MAURICE WALSH,
Stealing a jacket and other articles, and nine shillings, the goods and money of
Thomas Gascoigne. Second Count, receiving the same.

THOMAS GASCOIGNE . I am a seaman, living now at 97, Campbell Road, Finsbury Parkâ€”on 26th June I was employed on the Joseph, lying at Ollendorff's Wharfâ€”the prisoner, who was on board, offered to sell me an oilskin and south-wester, for which I agreed to pay one shillingâ€”I said I had no money on me because my money was below in my clothesâ€”I borrowed a shilling from the captain and paid the prisonerâ€”when I went below later I missed my blue jacket and vest and cloth trousers, a silver pencil-case from my vest pocket, and nine shillings, and a pocket
book from my jacket pocketâ€”these are the jacket and vest, the trousers have not been recoveredâ€”I missed the prisoner, and did not see him again till ho was in custodyâ€”there is no pretence for saying that I gave him the things in exchange for the oilskin and south-westerâ€”he said he had no money to go to London, would I buy this oilskin and southwester to pay his fare to London, and I agreed to buy them for one shilling.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I borrowed a shilling from the captain, because I had work to do aloftâ€”I was unloading a bargeâ€”the night before I paid for one lot of beer, and you for another.

Re-examined. I gave twenty-five shillings for the coat and vest a few weeks before, I had only worn them a few times; the trousers were worth about twelve shillings, and the pencil-case about four shillings; altogether the value of the things was about two poundsâ€”the oilskin and south-wester were not worth a shilling.

THOMAS TAYLOR ( WR 30). About 2.30 p.m. on 8th July I saw the prisoner in the Wandsworth Road, and said, "I shall take you into custody for stealing some clothing and nine shillings from a boat at the Victoria Docks "â€”he said, "Oh, I thought you wanted me for something else"â€”afterwards he said, "I have been expecting this"â€”I conveyed him to East Greenwich Police-stationâ€”on the way he said, "I changed an oilskin and a south-wester for the clothing, and Gascoigne gave me a shilling as well"â€”he was wearing this coat and vest when I took himâ€”none of the other things have been recovered.

WILLIAM STEVENS (Detective Thames Police). On 27th June I received informationâ€”on 8th July I found the prisoner detained at East Green
wich Police-stationâ€”I said, "How do you account for the possession of that coat and vest you are wearing?"â€”he said, "I gave a man an oil-skin coat and south-wester for them "â€”I said, "What man?"â€”he said, "A man on board the Joseph "â€”I said, "Do you mean Gascoigne?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”when charged with stealing these things he made no answer.
Prisoner's Defence, The prosecutor is telling a lot of falsehoods about his money. When I felt in the coat-pocket all it contained was a tin box with one farthing.

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony in March, 1890
.â€”Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

617.
JOHN COLEMAN,
Unlawfully and carnally knowing
Lydia Lavinia Harris, a girl under sixteen.
NOT GUILTY .

618.
WILLIAM HENRY PIGGOTT
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing Â£10, the money of his master,
Robert Chadwell;
also to marrying
Lavinia King during the lifetime of his wife.

619.
JOHN WILLIAMS (21)
, Robbery, with
William McBride and other persons, on
John Fergusson, and stealing a watch and other articles, his property.

JOHN FERGUSSON . I am a sailor, and lodge at Sloper's Dining Rooms, Manor Way, North Woolwichâ€”on Saturday night, June 14th, I was going down Beresford Street, Woolwich, to get across the water, and four men came up to me, assaulted me, and took away my watch and. guard, and ten or twelve shillingsâ€”one came in front and three behindâ€”they seized me by my throat, and hurt itâ€”the prisoner was one; he broke my

guard and stole my watchâ€”Mr. Armstrong came to my assistance, and they all ran up Beresford Street and turned up by Barnard's Theatre of Varietiesâ€”I next saw the prisoner about a fortnight afterwards; not in a group; he was in the office when I went in.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. This was about 12.30; it was under a lamp, but they took me away from the light.

THOMAS ARMSTRONG . I live at 92, Wellington Street, Woolwichâ€”about 12.30 on Sunday morning, 14th June, I was going down Beresford Street and saw four men opposite Barnard's Music Hallâ€”the prisoner is one, I am quite confidentâ€”they were standing speaking, and I watched themâ€”they went very slowly and made a haltâ€”I saw the prisoner a little way ahead, he joined a soldier, and they stoppedâ€”when I got by the Guild-hall the prisoner crossed to my side of the road; I went into a dark corner, and one of the men, McBride, went up to the prosecutor and said, "God blind me, why do you want to fight? "and the prisoner put his hand in the prosecutor's pocket, and I saw him breaking his chainâ€”I shouted out, and they ran away down by the side of the music-hallâ€”I called the soldier and we took the prosecutor to the stationâ€”on Wednesday, July 1st, I saw the prisoner in the Essex Arms, and pointed him out to the policeâ€”I had been looking out for him for sixteen nights every nightâ€”I have known him since last December.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor was going the same way as me towards the Arsenal, which was about eighty yards offâ€”he was going a little bit away from his boat, but he is a stranger in Woolwichâ€”after twelve o'clock at night he could not cross the waterâ€”last Christmas Eve was the first time you spoke to meâ€”I did not know your name, but I gave your description to the policeâ€”the soldier was ten or fifteen yards away when the robbery took placeâ€”only you and McBride used violence, but one of the others held his handsâ€”you put your hands in his pocket, and you choked himâ€”a little man who I did not know held his other hand.

JESSE BARTLE (R 403). On Wednesday, July 1st, about 10.15, Mr. Armstrong pointed out the prisoner to me at the door of the Essex public-houseâ€”I told him I should take him in custody for highway robbery on June 14thâ€”he said, "I do not know anything about it; you might have had me before if you had wanted me "â€”I had told him he was charged with McBride.

JOHN PATTERSON . I am a gunnerâ€”on this Saturday night I was in Beresford Street with Mr. Fergussonâ€”he went on some yards, and four men came behind usâ€”I afterwards saw him in the middle of the road, and saw the men running down the roadâ€”I did not see anything done to himâ€”the prisoner was among them; I am quite sure of that.

Cross-examined. I was perhaps thirty yards off; not near enough to see whether you did anything, but yet I recognise you as one of the four who committed the assaultâ€”I was at the Police-court before I was asked to recognise youâ€”I saw the men called in, and saw that you were not among themâ€”I was up and down the street, waiting till the case came on.

HARRY REES . I am potman at the Duke of Sussex, Beresford Streetâ€”I have known the prisoner about two monthsâ€”on Saturday, June 13th, I saw him in the Duke of Sussex at 10.50; he remained there till 11.20;

he was the worse for liquor, and I took him home and put him into bedâ€”he lives at the Casual Ward lodging-houseâ€”I saw no more of him till 12.25; he was then sound asleep in bedâ€”I heard of his being taken up on this charge, and went and gave my evidence, and was bound over.

Cross-examined. The Duke of Sussex is right opposite Barnard's Theatre, and thirty or forty yards from the Casual Ward lodging-houseâ€”I do not live at the Casual Ward now, I left last Saturdayâ€”I looked at the clock as I went inâ€”I can get away from business at any timeâ€”the Drill Hall is about 200 yards from the Duke of Sussexâ€”I am no relation of the prisonerâ€”I remained till 1.40 in the same room with him; I was attending to a man suffering from pleurisy, who is here.

JOHN O'CONNOR . I have known Rees about two monthsâ€”on Saturday, 13th June, I went to bed about 11.35 at the Casual Ward lodging-house, and remained in bed till about seven next morningâ€”I slept in the next bed to the prisoner, and saw him in bed when I went up to bed, and fast asleepâ€”he remained in bedâ€”I was examined before the Magistrate.
Cross-examined. There is no clock in the room, but there was a watch; I did not look at it till three o'clock next morningâ€”I am no relation of the prisoner.

WILLIAM HENRY ELLIS . I am a carmanâ€”on 13th June I was at this lodging house, in bed with pleurisy, when Rees brought the prisoner up drunk at 10.50, and put him into bedâ€”I know the time by my watchâ€”he remained in bed till 6.40 next morning.
Cross-examined. If any one had got out of bed and left the room I should have seen it, as I had not a wink of sleep all night.

GEORGE DAVIS . I am a fishmonger's assistant, of 21, Rope Yard Rails, Woolwichâ€”that is a lodging-houseâ€”I slept there on Saturday night, 13th Juneâ€”I went to bed about 11.30â€”the prisoner, who I had known about a fortnight, came in from 11.5 to 11.15 with the potman of the Duke of Sussex, and was taken upstairs and put to bedâ€”he was the worse for liquorâ€”I slept in the next bed to him on the other side, and there he slept all night.
Cross-examined. When I got up to bed I found him in bedâ€”I went to sleep about a quarter to twelve, and slept soundly till morning.
NOT GUILTY .

620.
GEORGE DUKE and
JAMES HITCHCOCK,
Conspiring together to cast away a barge, and to commit wilful damage to it.

ALFRED MARTIN . I am in the employ of Thomas Bevan, of North
fleetâ€”on 17th June I was in charge of his barge Alert, lying in the upper entrance of Albert Dockâ€”I got there about 12.30 at night; I had come down the riverâ€”I had to wait till the gates were open, when the tide came inâ€”two men, named Cross and Day, were on boardâ€”the head rope was tied to a ring, which was attached to a long chain which hung down from the pier-head; anyone could reach it even at low waterâ€”any barge going into the dock could be attached thereâ€”we were moored with a rope; we had no stern rope, only a line made fast to the barge we were lying alongside ofâ€”we were the outside barge, but there were five or six more between us and the jetty, lying head upâ€”there were more

barges astern of them, but not between us and the gateâ€”we made everything right, and went into the cabin to rest ourselves, down a ladder, through a scuttle, which is covered with a hatch, which works backwards and forwardsâ€”we left that open, and I went to sleepâ€”there are lockers or seats round the cabin, one is about two feet from the floor, and the other one foot nine inchesâ€”there is a skylight in the roof, it is large enough for a man's head to go through and look roundâ€”I awoke about 3.30, and the scuttle-hatch was pulled over closeâ€”I tried to open it, but could not, as it was fastenedâ€”I gave warning to my mates, and put a winch handle under the flushing-board and prized it up an inch, which enabled me to see forward, and I saw the two prisoners on board; Duke was about four feet abaft the mast; he picked up a coil of rope and took it off our barge and across two others, and threw it into the waterâ€”Hitch
cock made a rope fast to the ring and pulled from the shore towards our bargeâ€”that was our headfastâ€”I saw it pulled away from the ringâ€”I afterwards examined the rope and found it had been cut, and the other rope was let go which I had made fast to the barge, and we were com
pletely adriftâ€”I saw the prisoners shoving her astern down the riverâ€”they then went across the inside barges; I cannot say where they went toâ€”we then got an axe, prized open the scuttle-hatch, and let ourselves outâ€”a long iron bolt like this (produced) had been shoved into the place where the padlock goesâ€”when I got on deck I saw the two prisoners in a boat fifty yards offâ€”it was not a clear morning, but you could see a quarter of a mileâ€”Truss and I launched our boat, and followed them up the river for about an hour and a half; we were not fifty yards away from them at any timeâ€”they asked us if we had a bailerâ€”they rowed their boat ashore, but did not leave itâ€”I kept my eye on themâ€”they went to the tug Naples, and then to a dumb barge, and both went down the cabinâ€”a police galley came up in five minutes, and I informed the police, who went on board with meâ€”Hitchcock came up from the scuttle; Duke was below; I shouted for him, but he did not come at onceâ€”I charged them with wilfully cutting the barge adrift, and stealing rope; they said they knew nothing about itâ€”besides the things being thrown overboard, the ropes were all taken out, and the pump-spear, and breakâ€”that is used to keep the goods from being damaged by water, and if we were deprived of it the stuff would get wetâ€”the main cord was cut, which would cause greater risk of capsizingâ€”it was about 50 feet longâ€”we do not let both the lee-boards down at the same time, or when we went near the ground we should touch the bottomâ€”the one on the port side was let downâ€”the tide was ebbingâ€”supposing I had not woke up the barge might have turned over, and this rope being cut would make it more liable to turn overâ€”if it had gone to the mud banks on the other side the lee-board would have broke, and when we were drifting on the river we might have come against some ships or the piers of a bridgeâ€”we ran a great risk of destruction.

Cross-examined by Mr. BESLEY. The Alert is 60 or 70 feet longâ€”we had no topsailâ€”the sprit is about three-fourths the length of the barge; there were 90 tons of cement on board, and the barge was down very low; the gunwale was only three or four inches from the waterâ€”I am a licensed waterman and a lightermanâ€”I served six years' apprenticeship, and am subject to the regulations, one of which is that according to the size, the

barge shall have so many hands on board, and one licensed man if she is towed, but when she is cast off from the tug she must have twoâ€”when she is moored it is not necessary to have a man on boardâ€”we had come from a ship at Limehouse, and took in cargo at North-fleetâ€”she came up eight miles above the Albert Dockâ€”the tide began to run down at 9.25 at the bridge, and 9.19 at Limehouse, but we were towed backâ€”we began to be towed at eleven o'clock, and we had the tide in our favourâ€”the time would be an hour, or an hour and half; it depends on how many barges the tug had behind her, which I do not know, but only one stopped at the Albert Dockâ€”there may have been twenty barges there, some laden and some lightâ€”I fastened the rope to the ring myself, and had to go over five or six other barges to do itâ€”there were sixty or eighty feet of ropeâ€”I did not hear it asked for at the Police-courtâ€”I was not in Court when Day was examinedâ€”I saw the rope afterwards; it was not let go from our barge; it was cut near the shore endâ€”they could not cut it from the pier, out they could get down from the pier on to the other bargesâ€”I turned in about 1.30â€”I had not got a watchâ€”when I awoke it was guesswork, but I went by the state of the tide, which was ebbing slowly, and I should say it was between 3.30 and fourâ€”I saw sixty fathoms of half-inch rope thrown into the Thames; that would weigh one and a half hundredweight at the outsideâ€”the barge was not on the mud at low tideâ€”there is great depth of water there, fourteen feet, I thinkâ€”the Alert had moved ten feet when we left in our boatâ€”it did not take thirty seconds to launch itâ€”we left one man on the barge to prevent her going furtherâ€”it was not foggy, but it was hazyâ€”you can see a quarter of a mile at 3.30 a.m. at this time of yearâ€”some lightermen and watermen pick up jobs on the river if they have got a boat to do it withâ€”Hitchcock may have gone on board three barges, and then went into his own boat again; after he left the barge it was low waterâ€”it was low water at Woolwich at 4.40, and it then turnedâ€”the police took them in custody between 5 and 5.30 when we got on deck they were fifty yards away, and when we had launched our boat they were one hundredâ€”they pulled fifty yards against tide while we were getting our boat inâ€”we were more than thirty seconds on deck before we launched our boatâ€”there is not much tide at the entrance of the dockâ€”Silvertown is nearly a mile and a half from the entrance to the Albert Dock, or not quite so much.

Re-examined. Our boat was pulled up on the hatches that night, and in thirty seconds we removed it from there, and put it afloat, but we were on deck longer than thatâ€”I never lost sight of the prisoners; there was a slight eddy helping them upâ€”when Hitchcock went on board, Duke remained in the boatâ€”he had on a two-peaked cap, a tourist's cap, the one he had at the Police-court.

By MR. BESLEY. I had never seen the prisoners beforeâ€”I may know Hillman by sight; I do not know that his barge was lying next to the Alert, or that he wore a double-peak tourist's capâ€”I did not see him when the Alert arrivedâ€”these caps are not worn on the river muchâ€”this (produced) is the kind of cap, but it is darker.
Re-examined. Hillman (looking at him) is not the man I saw on my barge, nor the man in the boat which we followed.

ARTHUR TRUSS . I live at 47, Station Street, Northfleet, and am em
ployed

on the Alert by Mr. Bevanâ€”on the morning of June 9th the Alert was moored at the entrance of the Albert Dockâ€”Martin and Day were on boardâ€”she was made fast to the pier-head by a ring with a chainâ€”you can reach the ring from the bargeâ€”our other rope was made fast to a lighter alongsideâ€”I saw that everything was made right, and the two men and I went down to the cabinâ€”the scuttle-hatch was right openâ€”Martin awoke me in the morning, and the scuttle-hatch was fastened down; we were not able to open itâ€”Martin said something to me, and I rushed to the skylight, stood on the seat and put my head out, and saw the two prisoners on board; Duke picked up a coil of rope alongside the mast and threw it into the waterâ€”Hitchcock was pulling our headfast rope from the pier-headâ€”it was afterwards examined, and it had been cutâ€”the rope by which we were moored was let go, and we were all adriftâ€”Duke shoved our barge astern, and they went off our barge across some lighters, and I saw them come round the stern of our barge in a boatâ€”the scuttle-hatch was not then opened; I kept looking out while Martin smashed it with a windlass-handleâ€”we then got into our boat; this took about ten minutes, but we did not lose sight of themâ€”we followed them about an hour and a half up to the tug Naples, and they went on board and moored their boat to a lighter, and went down in the cabinâ€”we waited about five minutes for the police-galley to come up, and gave informationâ€”we moored our boat, and went on board with a policeman, and Hitchcock stood in the scuttle-hatch and shouted for Duke; he did not come up at first; he was supposed to be asleepâ€”a charge was preferred against themâ€”one rope of the barge was cut right through, which let the sprit go right round; that would be dangerous; if there was any wind it might break the other rope which holds the spritâ€”the whole of the pump apparatus was thrown overboard, and one of the lee
boards let downâ€”the barge drifted about twenty yardsâ€”Day was left in charge of it, when we followed the prisoners; and he let go the anchor to bring her upâ€”I had been asleepâ€”you. could see distinctly 100 or 140 yards that morning.

Cross-examined. I am not a waterman; I am a labourerâ€”I am about five feet highâ€”the cabin is so low that when I stood on the seat I had to stoop just a shadeâ€”there was no glass in the skylight, except in the centreâ€”I looked out at the top in the centre, not at the side; the top was not onâ€”the Alert has no topsailâ€”I could not see quite across the river; it was a little mistyâ€”I saw Duke on the deckâ€”I do not know that there was a watchman on the pier-headâ€”I saw men on board the other craftâ€”about seven minutes elapsed between Martin calling me and our getting out of the cabinâ€”I did not call out to anyone during those seven minutes, but I called Dayâ€”our boat was not launched when the other boat went round our stern, and if they had chosen they could have got clear away from usâ€”I did not see the rope cut attached to the prisoner's head, or see it let goâ€”I saw it thrown on boardâ€”I saw Hitchcock hand it up through the ring; none of the rope was left on the chainâ€”I saw Martin tie it up at nightâ€”I have seen the rope since, it was left on the bit-head, it was cut off four or five feet from the ringâ€”I do not suggest that the two men in the boat avoided meâ€”I made no complaint till the Thames wherry cameâ€”when I returned to the barge she had swung right round, she had shifted fifty yards; she was anchored thereâ€”the stern was up the river then, the
head was up beforeâ€”the other barges had all swung with the tide, and the Alert was in the middleâ€”there were twenty or twenty-five other barges there.

Re-examined. The other barges were moored, and when I saw the Alert at eight she was swinging by her anchorâ€”Duke went on a barge, and I heard him ask if they wanted any help, and Hitchcock asked if they wanted a drop of rumâ€”Duke had a peak cap on.

WALTER DAY . I live at Northfleetâ€”on 17th June I was acting as third hand on board the Alertâ€”I was asleep in the cabin with Martin and Trussâ€”Truss woke me up, and I found the scuttle-hatch fastened down; it was wide open when I went. to sleep, we could not get out of the cabinâ€”I stood on a locker, put my head through the skylight, but did not see either of the prisonersâ€”Martin got the hatch open, and I went on deck and saw the two prisoners in a boat about 40 yards offâ€”Truss and Martin rowed after themâ€”our headfast had been cut, and the other rope let go; we were completely adrift, and drifted about a dozen yardsâ€”the van was cut, and the lee
board let downâ€”I let go the anchor; the tiden was about ebbingâ€”I found this iron bolt, which I had never seen on board beforeâ€”Martin and Day were away quite three hoursâ€”it was a tarred rope made of hemp which moored us to the pier-head.

Cross-examined. Twenty barges or so were lying together when we arrived at midnight; I did not find any more in the morningâ€”I did not notice Mr. Hillman's barge Amazonâ€”what I call the skylight is not above the locker; you are obliged to lean forward a little bitâ€”my mates had commenced to undo the hatchway when I wokeâ€”there was no calling out to anyone on board any other craftâ€”I saw the rope put through the iron ring, I am sure it was not put round the chainâ€”I expected to find part of it in the ring, but did not, they must have cut the bowâ€”it is not here; I did not hear it asked for at the Police-courtâ€”I let down the anchor after I helped to launch the boatâ€”the Alert had then moved half her own lengthâ€”the other barges had not moved.

Re-examined. The other barges were not adriftâ€”it did not take us a minute to launch the boatâ€”it takes three or four feet of the end of the rope to take up a portion and make a knot, and if the knot was cut the whole thing would come offâ€”the Alert had drifted, and there was a space between her and the other bargesâ€”the barges are not allowed to lie about the entrance to the lock where they likeâ€”there were four barges between us and the jetty, all waiting to get into the lock.

ROBERT BEVAN . My father is the owner of the Alert; he is a cement manufacturer at Northfleetâ€”we lighter our own cement to the various steamships which export itâ€”prior to June 17th we had had disputes with our workmen, which are still going onâ€”there were 500 casks of cement on board the Alert, value about Â£175â€”wet spoils it at once; it sets it as hard as a rockâ€”the water was nearly level with the deck, and with the slightest collision it would be likely to be sunkâ€”if the men had not woke up, and she had been allowed to drift, she might have gone athwart a steamer at anchor, and tipped over, or she might have gone across the chain of a steamer, and gone overâ€”the sprit being loose would make that worseâ€”letting down the port lee-board would enable her to drift fasterâ€”there is an eddy on the other side which sets up the river, and the barge would

go up the eddy, and come right into the tidewayâ€”she might have come in contact with the powder hulks on the other side of the river; that is just where the ebb tide would sweep her, and they have very long moor
ing chainsâ€”there are always barges lying aboutâ€”I have put my head through the skylight of the barge, and was able to see right round, and fore and aftâ€”it is possible when the scuttle-hatch is battened down to open it, so as to see throughâ€”you might not see a man's boots, but you could see his face.

Cross-examined. My height is about 5 ft. 9 in.â€”the three men on board were shorter than meâ€”I had to throw my body in a sloping direction to look outâ€”I did not make the experiment at two or three a.m.â€”the Alert was towed to Limehouse, and came back because she had been to another ship which did not take the cargoâ€”she went along the steamers in the river which did not take her cargo, and then the tug took her down.

JOSEPH GODDARD (Thames Police Inspector). My duties range from Barking Creek to Greenwichâ€”the telegraph ship at Silvertown is within my limitsâ€”on 17th June I saw Martin and Truss at Mr. Tate's Wharf, Silvertown, and from the information they gave me I went to the barge Two Brothers, belonging to W. Arnoldâ€”they followed me on boardâ€”I saw Hitchcock on board, and said, "What are you doing here?"â€”I was in uniformâ€”he said, "What's up, governor?"â€”I said, "What are you doing here? "â€”he said, "Having a rest," and called Duke twiceâ€”it appeared that Duke was having a sleep in the cabinâ€”he came up, and I said to Martin, "Are these the two men?"â€”Martin said, "Yes, I can swear to them," and charged them with stealing two ropes and cutting the barge adriftâ€”Hitchcock said, "I am quite innocent of this; what an unfounded charge! "â€”I took them both in custody, and they were charged before a Magistrate at Woolwichâ€”I found a knife on each, and on Hitchcock's knife there was some tar and threads of hemp rope very minute, which have worn off, but here is a little bit of tar hereâ€”they were in a barge boatâ€”I was on duty from two to eight a.m.â€”I went down the opposite side to Silvertown, and I was abreast of that place at 3.30, and went down a little further, and got back to where I arrested the prisoners at 5.30â€”I had not seen them before that morning, but they might have passed me plying aboutâ€”I made some measurements on the barge by the Magistrate's request: the height of the cabin is six feet, and from the floor to the top of the lockers is twenty-two inches, and from the top of the lockers to the ceiling four feet two inches; from the top of the locker to the top of the skylight is four feet six and a half inchesâ€”the opening of the skylight is nine inches long fore and aft, and seven inches athwartâ€”I put my head through, and got it out again.

Cross-examined. I do not think you could get your head throughâ€”the locker was not immediately underneath, and I had to steady myself with both handsâ€”I had my knees bent a littleâ€”I think a shorter man could do itâ€”three men were rowing the police boat, and I was steering, and heard someone say, "I want you, officer," and went towards the boat in which Martin wasâ€”we pulled to a barge which was half on the ground, I am not sure whether she was afloat at allâ€”the Naples was not attached to the other bargesâ€”I do not know whether Duke was asleep; he looked very sleepy when I saw his face, and he wanted a lot of callingâ€”it is
usual for men who have not constant employment to row about to get jobs.
Re-examined. It is usual for the men to apply for jobs to the master lightermen and the society, but they go out in boats to see that the barges are properly moored.

JAMES CRIPPS . I am a master lighterman, and know this localityâ€”there would be a strong eddy running up against the ebb for a considerable distanceâ€”the wind was south-west, coming right out of the dock, and a barge cast adrift would go up the eddy, and the lee-board being let down on the port side the tide would catch upon her and take her up more rapidly; she would then meet the ebb, and if she came in contact with the powder barges, being deeply loaded, she would sinkâ€”there were twenty or thirty barges about thereâ€”if the three men were shut down in the cabin asleep they would run a great risk of being drowned.

Cross-examined. I know from my diary that the wind was S. W.â€”I cannot tell what it was at six o'clock the morning before, because I have not got my diary hereâ€”I write my diary at nine and at six from my compass, and correct it from H. M. Customs opposite.

ROBERT SHORING . I am a lighterman, of 58, Dale Street, Canning Townâ€”on June 17th I was night watchman at the Telegraph Works, Silvertownâ€”we took in the lights at 2.30 a.m., as it was daylightâ€”about half or three-quarters of an hour after that I saw the two prisoners in a boat, and said, "Good morning, George"â€”they said, "Good morning, Bob," and rowed down inside the ship Silvertown, which was taking in telegraph cableâ€”they rowed towards the Naples tug, which was sixty or seventy yards ahead, or a little moreâ€”I saw them row towards the ship, and I put the engineer ashore and rowed backâ€”the prisoners were dodging about and boarding sailing craftâ€”I did not see them go on board the Naplesâ€”they were in my sight from 3.15 to 5.15â€”I was in my boat to row people, ashoreâ€”I saw the prisoners taken out of the Two Brothers by the policeâ€”it is about a mile and a quarter from the ship Silvertown to the entrance of the Albert Docks; there is only one entrance, and that is about a mile and a quarter from where I exchanged words with themâ€”it was ebb tide; it would take half an hour to row down, and three-quarters of an hour to row upâ€”they were under my observation from the time I spoke to them till the police took them; there was no time for them to go down and come back without my missing themâ€”it is not unusual for men to go about asking for jobsâ€”I saw plenty of other boats in the river.

Cross-examined. I cannot give the names of any other person's boats that morning; they were strange boatsâ€”there were some small boatsâ€”I will not swear the tide was ebbing at five; I believe it wasâ€”I had no watch; I go by the state of the tideâ€”when the tide is ebbing, an hour and a half before low water, a small boat could not go down from the Albert Dock to Silvertown in a quarter of an hour with two men rowing, and I do not think in twenty minutesâ€”I was a watch
manâ€”I took people from the ship to the shore, which is three hundred and sixty odd feet, every quarter of an hour for two or three hoursâ€”it was good daylight at 2.30; I could clearly distinguish eighty or ninety yards offâ€”you could not see quite so far at 3.30, because it was a bit foggyâ€”there is no gangway from the ship to the shoreâ€”the ship is

about three hundred and fifty feet longâ€”I was all round the ship watch
ingâ€”the prisoners were rowing all about the river, boarding first one ship and then anotherâ€”I will swear I saw them every half-hour, not every quarterâ€”I am not a union manâ€”I have got my license with meâ€”I did not take notes of the names of the sailing barges the prisoners went on board of, because I did not know I was going to be askedâ€”lighter
men ply for work night and dayâ€”they go to a place in the City, as a rule, between six and seven o'clockâ€”there would be work to do at the lowest of ebb-tide going up the river; the way to catch them is to go down an hour or half an hour before low waterâ€”they might go to Rochester or Gravesendâ€”two men as a rule are on board these barges, the captain and mate; I have been master of a bargeâ€”sailing barges could not go down that morning, it was low waterâ€”I do not suppose there would be anybody at the wharves before six a.m.â€”they would begin to go up the river about 5.16 with the flood-tide, and then the men would be on the look out for work; I should not expect them to be asleep at 5.15.

Re-examined. I did not see the prisoners go on board the Two Brothersâ€”there was nothing wrong about them being on board ready to go up the river when the tide turnedâ€”officers look out for any infringement of the law for navigating a barge without two on board; they go on board and say, "Have you got a license, old man?" and if they have not you can complain.

By the COURT. A lighterman who is looking out for a job can claim the job if there is no waterman on boardâ€”there is a penalty for working without a licenseâ€”if a lighterman is going from one vessel to another he inquires if there is a license; if there is not he claims the penalty, and if there is he claims the job.

HENRY FREDERICK RUSSELL . I was captain of the tug Naples on 17th Juneâ€”I had come to London and back, tugging up dumb barges to Harborough. Southwark Bridgeâ€”I had no barges going backâ€”I got down to Mr. Tate's buoy about 10.50 and moored there, and the prisoners came in a boat about three o'clock, and Hitchcock asked me to give them a sleepâ€”I judge the time by the tideâ€”I said, "There is no room here; go on board one of the master's barges inside"â€”that was the Two Brothersâ€”they got there in their boat, but I did not see them go there; I did not come up out of the cabinâ€”they did not give me their names; I knew them.

Cross-examined. I was sleeping in my cabinâ€”I fell asleep again, but I know it was three o'clockâ€”I did not finish smoking till twelveâ€”I was sleeping aft, and the mate alsoâ€”he did not get up, but he woke up.
Re-examined. Hitchcock came to the cabin hatchway, and I could see him plainlyâ€”I knew him beforeâ€”he said there was a man with him; it is a general thing to do.
By the COURT. I had no watchâ€”I thought it might be about that timeâ€”I had been out the night before, and was very tired.

GEORGE BOWDEN . I am an apprentice to a watermanâ€”I was with Russell on board the Naples tugâ€”we left London at 9.30 a.m., and got down about 10.45; we had a quarter of an hour against tideâ€”the engineer and stoker went ashore about 10.40, and we turned in about twelveâ€”I slept in the same cabin with Russellâ€”between two and three o'clock I saw Hitchcock; I did not see the man with him, but I heard himâ€”I heard Russell give them leave to go somewhereâ€”I judge the

time by the state of the tideâ€”I saw them again three or four days after
wards.
Cross-examined. I was very tired, and wanted to go to sleep; I just spoke to him and went to sleep again.

JOHN KEYS . I am a lighterman, of 19, Heath Street, Commercial Roadâ€”on June 16 I lent my boat to Hitchcock for a day or two to get his livingâ€”it is red, white, and blueâ€”there are four or five hundred boats on the river painted like that.
Cross-examined. It is a barge boat.

CHARLES HILLMAN . I am a lighterman, of 218, Cable Street, St. George's-in-the-Eastâ€”on the evening of June 16 I was in charge of the Amazon, and got to the pier-head, Albert Dock, about 12.30 on the 17thâ€”it is a dumb barge; no one was on board but meâ€”I made fast to a barge of W. Pope and Co.â€”there were about twenty barges at the pier-headâ€”the Alert was not there when I arrivedâ€”I saw her come; she laid outside another barge, and I saw a man run over the craft with a ropeâ€”I was wearing a cap the same shape as this, but thicker and darkerâ€”it is at home; I have two or three like it, I have two on board the bargeâ€”they are very usual among river menâ€”there is always a watchman on the pier-headâ€”I heard nothing to alarm me in the nightâ€”about six a.m. I saw the Alert with her anchor down; she had swung round with the tideâ€”I saw nothing of the cutting of the ropeâ€”she had not shifted any distance, she had only swung roundâ€”I was on board the Amazon till break of day, a little after two, and then I went below and turned inâ€”the Alert was there then, and no alarm was made.
Cross-examined. I am not the man with the peak cap who cut the rope.

THOMAS JAMES BELLMAN . I live at 7 G, Peabody Buildings, Ber
mondseyâ€”on 17th June I was on the Nelsonâ€”I got to Albert Dock between twelve and one, and saw the Alert arrive, and another barge, called the Silver Weddingâ€”the Alert was made fastâ€”I turned in about 2.30â€”I next saw the Alert about 5.30, swung up at the entrance of the dock, in the midst of the craft, with her anchor downâ€”she was only a few yards from us beforeâ€”she swung round with all the othersâ€”I did. not know of any rope being cutâ€”there is a watchman on duty at the pier-head; I saw him when we came down, I did not see him when I woke upâ€”the bottom there is mud, and the anchor would hold in it very fast.

THOMAS HOLLIGAN . I live at 16, Tender Road, Bermondseyâ€”on 17th June I was on board the Lascar; she was moored to the pier-headâ€”we arrived there at 12.30â€”I turned in at 2 or 2.30; the Alert was all right thenâ€”I was not alarmed in the nightâ€”about one o'clock I saw the prisoners come to the Tilbury tug and tow away down the river towards Barking, that is not towards Silvertownâ€”the Alert had not arrived then.
Cross-examined. It would take them an hour or an hour and a half to row from Barking to Silvertown.

CHARLES LEVETT . I am lock-man at the Albert Docksâ€”there are two entrances close together, but the depth of water is differentâ€”the upper entrance with the least amount of water is used by bargesâ€”I went on duty at 8.30 and left at 6 a.m.â€”I passed the night there, and walked aboutâ€”I did not see the Alert come, but I saw her there at 2 a.m. and again at 3.30, amongst nineteen or twenty other craftâ€”it is the rule to require one man on board eachâ€”I did not see Martin and Truss go away in their boat; I heard nothing of it till 4.30, when a man came ashore

from the barge to the upper pier-head in a boat, and came in front of meâ€”the Alert was then swung up, and there were about three craft inside her and fifteen or sixteen outside her; the tide was coming up, and that swung all the craft upâ€”I do not know what was holding her, I took it that she was fastâ€”she could not have got loose so as to float against the powder vesselâ€”she could have got away from the other craft if she had been loosenedâ€”a person could descend the steps and get on board the craftâ€”they can come and go as they please.
Cross-examined. The barges are not all in regular orderâ€”they must all take their turn to go into the lock.
Re-examined. Barges do not always swing in the same way, and if the barges get a cant in they stop inâ€”their position gets altered very much.

GUILTY .â€”
Six Months' Imprisonment each.

621.
GEORGE DUKE and
JAMES HITCHCOCK were again indicted for
stealing 20 fathoms of rope.
Also for feloniously attempting to cast away a vessel. No evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

622.
ROBERT BEADSHAW (54) was indicted
for and also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the wilful murder of
Emma Ann Bradshaw.

MESSES. CHARLES MATHEWS , A. F. GILL, and ELDRIDGE Prosecuted; Ms. PURCELL Defended at the request of the Court. James Chapman, Police Sergeant M 15, produced and proved three plans of the premises in question.

EMMA JANE WILDE . I am a daughter of the prisonerâ€”latterly I have been living at 40, Palatinate Buildings, Kent Roadâ€”on Monday, 29th June, I went with my mother, the deceased, to Southwark Police-court to apply for a summons against my father for threatsâ€”on Saturday, 4th July, about twenty minutes past twelve, I went to 24, Smith's Buildings, where my father and mother livedâ€”I there saw my father, mother, Alfred Hodson, and my sister Mariaâ€”the prisoner said to me that he would bring b----authority (meaning my husband) down to give me a good hidingâ€”I replied, "You ought to be ashamed of yourself, knowing that we have been parted nearly two years"â€”my husband and I had been parted two years come next Marchâ€”he said, "Do you intend to carry out this summons? "â€”he said that to me and my motherâ€”we were in the kitchen; she was cleaning out the kitchenâ€”we both answered, "Yes"â€”he said, "Oh, neither you nor your mother shall live to see this on Monday "â€”the summons was to come off on Mondayâ€”he had had the summons; I believe lie had just burnt itâ€”I did not see him burn itâ€”he then walked upstairs, got a parcel, came down, and walked out with it under his armâ€”after that I went a little way with mother to get the boys' dinner inâ€”I think it must have been about twenty minutes past one when I left her at the Bricklayers' Arms, Ber
mondsey New Roadâ€”that was about five or ten minutes' walk from her homeâ€”I next saw her about half-past twoâ€”she was then deadâ€”I have often heard my father threaten my poor mother; for years he has
threatened her lifeâ€”he has said, "I will do for you," and once, that he knew he would be hung for her.

Cross-examined. It is nine years since I lived with them in the same houseâ€”I very rarely went to the house in the week, but always every Saturday morningâ€”I believe my father has not been working at the wharf for four or five yearsâ€”he was supported by his wife and children, on and offâ€”I believe he has hardly earned anything; it never benefited motherâ€”I never knew him to ail anythingâ€”I do not know that at the wharf he was called "Mad Bradshaw"; this is the first I have heard of itâ€”I only know one man who worked there with himâ€”he worked with him for twenty yearsâ€”I did not hear that he sometimes behaved there in a very peculiar and odd wayâ€”he has been given to drink for years, as long as lean recollectâ€”I am twenty-nine years of ageâ€”on one occasion he was at Rotherhithe Infirmary for some illness brought on by drinkâ€”I should say that was from five to eight years agoâ€”he has not to my knowledge been to any other infirmary or hospitalâ€”on a former occasion a summons for threats was taken out against him, but mother did not appear, because he said he would, turn over a new leafâ€”I could not say how long ago that wasâ€”I should think it was from two to three yearsâ€”when sober he has behaved kindly to herâ€”since he left off working at the wharf he has been doing odd jobs at homeâ€”I don't know what he did otherwise; of course, now and again he was at homeâ€”I have not been at home muchâ€”there are seven children living; I am the eldestâ€”Maria is at home, and Samuel, ten years oldâ€”when we were young he was a very good father to usâ€”he has been on good terms with me latterlyâ€”the authority he referred to was my husbandâ€”there has not been any difference between me and father lately about my husbandâ€”we have always been on good termsâ€”I went with mother about the summons on this last occasionâ€”I believe father was in the militia seven years; I do not know that he was discharged from the militia on account of his healthâ€”my brother was a baby when he joined, and he is twenty this month.

Re-examined. I cannot fix the date of the first summons; I should think it was within two yearsâ€”after serving in the militia I believe father went to work at Hayes' Wharf, and remained there a great number of years; I do not know when he leftâ€”he afterwards worked at Butler's Wharf as a cooperâ€”he has been drinking ever since I can remember; not continually; he would have bouts of drinking, and sometimes he would go withoutâ€”I never noticed him to be violent when in drinkâ€”the threats would be more often when he had drink; I have not known him utter threats when sober; I can hardly recollectâ€”I did not notice that he had had any drink on the morning of 4th July; as far as I could see, he was sober; he seemed perfectly calmâ€”he had not been drinking to excess before that; he had not the money to do soâ€”I could not tell how long before that I had seen him under the influence of drink.

MARIA MAUD BRADSHAW . I am fifteen years of ageâ€”in July this year I was living at 24, Smith's Buildings, Long Lane, Bermondsey, with my father and motherâ€”I had been there about two months before 4th Julyâ€”there were four rooms; a kitchen and parlour on the ground floor, and two bedrooms on the first floor; my father and mother occupied the front room, and the boys had the back roomâ€”I slept in the same room as father and motherâ€”in the week ending on Saturday, the 4th, a summons was

left at the houseâ€”I did not see my father with itâ€”on the 4th I came home about eleven in the morning, with my sister Emma, from the warehouse where we workâ€”we worked at umbrellas and parasols, and brought our work homeâ€”mother was in the kitchen; father was upstairsâ€”he came down into the kitchen, and said to my sister that he should bring authority down to her that night to fight herâ€”she said, "If you do I shall give you in charge "â€”she is living apart from her husband, whose name is Wilde, and is living with Brett; she is called both Mrs. Wilde and Mrs. Brettâ€”I went into the parlour and remained there some little timeâ€”father went upstairs, and came down with a bundle under his arm, and left the houseâ€”I did not hear what passed between them in the kitchenâ€”about ten minutes after father had gone out mother and Samuel went out; about twenty minutes afterwards father came back without the bundleâ€”he said, "Where is your mother gone?"â€”I said, "I don't know "â€”he went upstairs for a few minutes, and then went out againâ€”about a quarter of an hour after that mother returnedâ€”she got the dinner ready, and we sat down to dinner; mother, young Hodson, who was living in the house, and my little brother aged tenâ€”while we were at dinner father returned; he looked into the kitchen; mother asked him if he would have a bit of dinnerâ€”he said no, he did not require any, and he went upstairsâ€”he stayed there a few minutes, and then came down with a jug, and went out into the yard for a jug of waterâ€”he did not come into the kitchen, he passed the doorâ€”I could see him; he filled the jug with water, and came backâ€”as he came into the passage mother asked him if he would have a cup of tea insteadâ€”he said, "I have got a jug of water, that is sufficient, that is my allowance"â€”she said, "What is the good of telling lies, father?"â€”she asked him if he would have a piece of beefâ€”he said no, he did not require it, and went upstairsâ€”about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour afterwards he called out that he would have a cup of teaâ€”mother sent my little brother up to ask him if he would have it up or down stairs, and I heard him say, "Tell your mother to bring it up to me "â€”mother got the tea ready, and took it up to himâ€”I could not say in what room he wasâ€”I asked mother if I should take it up, and he said, "I don't require you "â€”then mother went upâ€”I remained in the kitchenâ€”after she had gone up I heard him say, "Will you withdraw the summons?"â€”she replied, "No; I have done it times enough "â€”I then heard him say, "If you will not withdraw it I will withdraw you"â€”she said, "If you touch me I will scream murder "â€”I was then at the bottom of the stairs, listeningâ€”it seemed to me that they were in a room, but which room they were in I could not sayâ€”I could hear distinctlyâ€”there is a bend in the staircaseâ€”I heard mother scream "Murder! "and "Police!" and I ran up the stairs and went to the front bedroom doorâ€”I could not open it; as I went to turn the handle I heard the key turned from inside, that locked the doorâ€”upon that I ran downstairs and out of the houseâ€”I saw Mrs. Chapman, a neighbour, and went back to the house with herâ€”the door was then shut; it had slammed after me when I left the houseâ€”I could not open it, as I had no keyâ€”whilst I was standing there I heard some smashing of glass insideâ€”I knocked at the door, father opened itâ€”I said, "Oh, father, what have you done? "â€”he said, "I have done it, Maria; I have done it; I have got my revenge "â€”he came out and went away; he had his hat onâ€”I went upstairs into the front bedroom, and there saw my

mother lying on the ground; she was alive, but unable to speakâ€”I saw a wound in her throat, from which she was bleedingâ€”a little time after
wards the police came, and then a doctor, and father was brought back to the house by a constable.

Cross-examined. I went out on Saturday morning about half-past nine, and came back at elevenâ€”father was in when I came backâ€”he went out twice, and was absent about twenty minutes each timeâ€”when he came back the first time he sent for some beer; my little brother got it, and took it upstairs to himâ€”that was before he had the jug of water; he got that to sponge some clothes that he was doing, some tailoring, in the boys' room, some job that he had brought homeâ€”it was about twenty minutes or half an hour after that that he asked for the teaâ€”father has been very much given to drink; I have often seen him very much the worse for liquor; he would then be noisy and use violent languageâ€”I have always been living at home, going out for work and coming home to my mealsâ€”I saw father every dayâ€”he has not been kind to mother and me when sober; he never was kind to meâ€”there have been frequent quarrels and disputes between him and his childrenâ€”my sister did not live at homeâ€”he was sometimes kind to mother, but not to meâ€”besides Samuel there are three more brothers who live at home; one is away in Indiaâ€”there are three at home besides my little brother; the youngest is 10, another 18, and another 21, and the eldest 24â€”none of the three were there on this Saturday; they go out to workâ€”they did not come home till after this had happenedâ€”they sometimes" come home in the afternoon; two work in the neighbourhood, and one in the City; they all three sleep at homeâ€”the prisoner for years past has been supported by his sons and daughtersâ€”I and mother used to work at umbrella workâ€”I could not exactly say how long it is since father worked at a wharf; it is years since he did do workâ€”the tailoring he did was odd jobs for his work
matesâ€”it is some years since he was in regular workâ€”I was very young when he used to go regularly to the wharfâ€”I remember when he was at the Rotherhithe Infirmaryâ€”he was not at Bartholomew's Hospital that I know; once he was under it with a bad coughâ€”he has sometimes behaved in rather an odd way, and done remarkable thingsâ€”he has been in the habit of sleeping with dangerous weapons under his pillow, sometimes a razor, sometimes a chopper, and sometimes a piece of iron, and that has often occurred, and for some time past, for yearsâ€”on the Thursday night before this he was sleeping with a chopper under his pillowâ€”I never heard him called "Mad Bradshaw. "

Re-examined, On Thursday night, 2nd July, he slept with a chopper under his pillowâ€”I did not hear him make any statement about itâ€”before then he had slept with a razor and a piece of iron there; that was at different timesâ€”latterly lie did some work for his mates at Butler's Wharfâ€”it is turned two years now since he did a day's work, since then he has done little tailorings for the men he used to knowâ€”it was about half-past one when he sent for a pint of beer; mother had just come in then; to my knowledge he had no more beer that dayâ€”he was not in drink when he came in and asked where mother wasâ€”it was while I was at dinner that he sent for the beer; he was free from drink then to my knowledgeâ€”it was after the beer had been taken up that he came down for the water; it was a different jug that he brought down for the
water; I saw no more of that jugâ€”he had not drank the beer when he said, "That is my allowance"â€”as far as I saw he seemed free from drink when he went upstairs.

By the JURY. When he put the things under his pillow he did not utter any threatsâ€”they were generally under his pillowâ€”mother was in fear of her life; she wanted to sleep with me, but he would not have itâ€”she knew the things were under the pillow, but she was in fear.

ALFRED HODSON . I am a labourer, and lodge at 24, Smith's Buildings; my room was opposite the prisoner's, on the same landing; some of the sons slept in the room with meâ€”on 4th July I came home about half-past twelveâ€”I went into the kitchen; Mrs. Bradshaw, Mrs. Wilde, and Maria were there; the prisoner was upstairsâ€”I did not hear any conversation between the prisoner, Mrs. Wilde, and the deceased at that timeâ€”he went out, and returned about a quarter or twenty minutes past oneâ€”Mrs. Bradshaw and Mrs. Wilde had then gone outâ€”I remarked to him about the weatherâ€”he said it did not matter to him about the weather, which way it was; it was pouring with rain at the timeâ€”he seemed quite soberâ€”he went upstairsâ€”I had dinner with Mrs. Bradshaw, Maria, and the little boyâ€”I saw the prisoner come downstairs carrying a jugâ€”Mrs. Bradshaw asked him if he would have any teaâ€”he said, "No; I am going to get some water to sponge with; I don't mind a cup of tea presently "â€”he got the water and went upstairsâ€”Mrs. Bradshaw told the boy to go up and ask him if he would have some tea, and he called down, "Tell your mother to bring it up "â€”Mrs. Bradshaw took it upâ€”Maria went round the bend towards the stairs, and I heard her say, "What are you going to do now? "or something to that effectâ€”I heard Mrs. Bradshaw call; I can't say whether it was "help" or "murder"â€”I ran out of the kitchen, and met Maria running down the stairsâ€”she ran out first, and I followed her, and the door shut be
hind meâ€”I ran up to the top, and met Constable Archer, and just as I was speaking to him the prisoner came along and said, "I am going down to Bermondsey Street to give myself up; I have just murdered the old woman"â€”the constable took him back to the house.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner four or five yearsâ€”I and the four sons occupied the one room opposite the prisoner'sâ€”he always appeared all right with his eldest daughterâ€”the sons and he were occa
sionally on bad terms; it was not the sons' fault if they did quarrel; the prisoner was repeatedly drunkâ€”I have often seen him the worse for liquorâ€”I can't say exactly raving like a madman or violent, but behaving very roughâ€”I never noticed him saying something and then stopping in the middle in forgetfulness, and odd in mannerâ€”his manner on this day did not strike me as peculiarâ€”he seemed no different to what he was at other timesâ€”if you spoke to him sometimes he would answer all right, and sometimes he would insult you without any cause; that did not strike me as odd, I was used to it, that was his habitâ€”I never heard him called "Mad Bradshaw"â€”I had not seen much of him that week, I was out nearly all day; sometimes I came home to dinner in the middle of the day, but I did not see much of himâ€”when he had anything to do he did it up in our bedroom; he was a good deal by himself upstairs doing work or sewingâ€”I knew that he sometimes carried a chopper or razor; he carried the chopper in his leather belt with a hole in it; sometimes he would pawn itâ€”he mostly carried the razor; he often carried the chopper
in his belt for some time past, for weeks, not for the last year, before thatâ€”I can't speak about the piece of iron or the fileâ€”he used the chopper in his business at the wharf.

Re-examined. This is the chopper, it was always brightly polished; he used to wear it up to about twelve months ago, up to the time he was working at the wharfâ€”I cannot fix the time precisely when I last saw him wearing it.

By Mr. PURCELL. I could not say when he was last working; at the wharf, I saw him just after last Christmas, and he was not doing any work thenâ€”the razor he occasionally carried in his pocket; the last time I saw that was about a fortnight agoâ€”it was such a razor as the one producedâ€”I have seen him with a file like this, not carrying it, but using it in the yard or scraping his bootsâ€”when I say he would sometimes insult you, I mean he would speak off-hand, as if he did not care whether he spoke to you or notâ€”he would say it did not matter a b----to him, or something like that; he would turn the thing away as indifferent to him.

ELIZA CHAPMAN: I am the wife of Stephen Chapman, a stoker; I live at 9, Victoria Place, Long Lane, which is the next turning to Smith's Buildingsâ€”I knew the prisoner and his wifeâ€”on Saturday, 4th July, about a quarter-past two, Maria Bradshaw came to my houseâ€”in conse
quence of what she said I went with her to her homeâ€”she knocked at the street door; we could not get any answer; she put her back to it and tried to force it openâ€”we heard a breaking of glass in the front room downstairsâ€”we stopped two or three minutes, and the prisoner then came and opened the doorâ€”Maria said, "Oh, father, what have you done? "â€”he said, "Oh, Maria, I have done it; I have had my revenge"â€”he then walked out of the house; Maria ran up the stairs, and I fol
lowed her into the front room, where I saw Mrs. Bradshaw lying on the floor, bleeding from wounds in the throatâ€”she died about five minutes afterâ€”I came down with Maria, and stopped there till the prisoner came in with the constable.

Cross-examined. When I afterwards went into the front room down
stairs I found the son's likeness was smashed and the glass was brokenâ€”I did not notice anything else damagedâ€”they were neighbours of mine for about six monthsâ€”I have heard the prisoner halloa to his children and his wife, but I never heard him quarrel with her or any
body; I have heard him act. like a madman; things that he said and the way he said themâ€”I never noticed him the worse for drinkâ€”I did not see much of them.

Re-examined. I have known him act violentlyâ€”he seemed to halloa in his talking; he would raise his voice and speak very loudly to the daughters and sonsâ€”he would halloa if the girl was doing anything for about five minutesâ€”that has been almost all the time he has been next door; I have not heard him speak loudly to his wife, only to the boys and girlsâ€”I never heard him quarrel with his wifeâ€”when I have heard him speak loudly I have not seen him; I have always been in
doors,

SARAH JANE GOUGH . I live at 26, Smith's Buildings, and am the wife of Charles (rough, a horsekeeperâ€”on Saturday, 4th July, about a quarter-past two I heard a noise coming from 24â€”I heard the prisoner's voice and his wife's, but not what they saidâ€”I saw Maria come out of the

houseâ€”I went to the door of No. 24 and tried to open it, but could notâ€”as I stood there I heard the prisoner say, "I told you I would do it"â€”some time after he opened the doorâ€”I did not see Maria then, or Mrs. Chapmanâ€”I did not hear glass breakingâ€”Maria was with meâ€”I heard the prisoner's voice coming from the first floor front, and I heard a fall as if from the same roomâ€”it was after that that the prisoner opened the doorâ€”he said, "I have done it, and I am going to Bermondsey station to give myself up," and he went in that directionâ€”I did not notice whether he had a hat or cap onâ€”I went in and went up to the first floor, and there saw Mrs. Bradshaw lying on the floor bleeding.

Cross-examined. When the prisoner came to the door he appeared to me more like a madman, he seemed to be wild and deranged; his eyes were pretty nigh out on his cheek bones, and he was saturated with bloodâ€”he spoke very mild, he did not shake; it was only his appear
ance, not his language, that seemed like a madmanâ€”I had only lived there about eight weeksâ€”I have seen him with a parcel which I supposed to be his work.

Re-examined. He spoke quietlyâ€”the way he looked was like a madmanâ€”his hands were covered with blood, not his faceâ€”when a man is in a desperate bad temper he looks different from what he is when he is in an amiable temper; he looked very angryâ€”I never saw Mrs. Chapman till after I came downstairsâ€”I then saw her in the back kitchen.

ARTHUR LOCKHART (M 69). I am the warrant officer at Southwark Police-courtâ€”I produce a summons dated 29th June, taken out by Emma Bradshaw against Robert Bradshaw, for threats; it was returnable on 6th Julyâ€”I served a copy of it on 3rd July on the wife, at 24, Smith's Buildings.

WILLIAM ARCHER (M 212). On Saturday, 4th July, between a quarter and half-past two I was proceeding up Long Lane when I received a com
munication from Hodson, inconsequence of which I stopped the prisoner; he was coming towards meâ€”he said, "I have murdered my old woman; I have done it all right, to please everybody; I am going to Bermondsey Street Station to give myself up "â€”I took him back to 24, Smith's Buildings, and in the first floor front room I saw a woman lying on her back, with several wounds on her face and throatâ€”Rickman, M 267, went up with me; I sent him for a doctor, and Dr. Martin returned with him the prisoner was in the room all the timeâ€”I took him into custody, and took him to the station; on the way he said, "If I had a chopper I would chop her head off "; he repeated that several timesâ€”I searched the room; I saw this razor and file lying on the floor close to the dead womanâ€”the prisoner said, "There is the razor and file I did it with "â€”at the station, in answer to the charge, he said, "Quite right"â€”he seemed very much excited; I think he was sober.

Cross-examined. I had seen him before about the street, as I might see anyone else; I had never heard him called after as "Mad Bradshaw"â€”he repeated the expression, "I wish I had a chopper; I would have chopped her head off." more than once on the way to the station, and the other expression also.

WILLIAM RICKMAN (M 267). On 4th July I went to 24, Smith's Build
ings, about half-past two, and there found the prisoner in the custody of last witnessâ€”I went for Dr. Martin, and on returning the prisoner was about to make a statement; I told him that what he said might be used
in evidence against him; he replied, "Quite right, I own to it; do a job properly and please everybody "â€”he seemed very excited, I think he was sober.

DAVID WILLIAMS (Inspector M).
