On 4th July I was in charge of the Police-station in Upper Grange Road, Bermondsey, when the prisoner was brought in by Archer, who handed me this razor and file; I then went with the constable to 24, Smith's Buildings, and there saw the woman lying dead in the first floor front; I returned to the station and charged the prisoner with the wilful murder of his wifeâ€”he said, "Quite right," which he repeated two or three times on his way to the cellâ€”a constable searched him in my presence; when he took off his coat he was wearing this shirt, which had stains of blood on it, showing that he was not wearing his coat when he committed the murder, because it was stained quite up to his shoulders, and his hands were stained with blood.

FRANCIS JOSEPH CLIFTON MARTIN . I am a registered medical practitioner of 33, Bermondsey Squareâ€”about twenty minutes past two on the after
noon of 4th July I was called to 24, Smith's Buildingsâ€”I there saw the body of a woman lying on her back on the ground in the first floor front room, used as a bedroom; she was deadâ€”I saw that she had several large cuts in the throatâ€”I made a post-mortem examination the next dayâ€”on the right side of the throat I found a large cut about seven inches long and an inch and a half deep, extending from two and a half inches behind, and one or half below the right ear to the middle of the chin, three-quarters of an inch below the lip; the bone was exposed from the angle of the jaw to the middle of the chinâ€”the jugular vein had been cut into, but not the carotid artery, it had cut open the pharynx and through the posterior half of the sterno musclesâ€”the direction of the wound was from before, backwards, and downwards; it had cut into the bone, showing consider
able forceâ€”on the left lower part of the chin were four superficial wounds about an inch and a half long and 1-16th of an inch deep, three deeper wounds on the left side, one immediately below the angle of the jaw; on the back of the left arm was a cut two and a half inches above the wrist, an inch and a quarter long and about an inch deepâ€”all these wounds were such as could be inflicted by such a razor as the one producedâ€”the immediate cause of death was the hemorrhage from the wound on the right side of the throat; that was a very grave wound, and must have been inflicted with considerable forceâ€”the other wounds were severe enough to cause deathâ€”I also observed some punctured wounds, two of them above and to the left of the navel, both penetrating the wall and coats of the stomachâ€”there were also fourteen other punctured wounds, slight in character, on the trunk, arms, and legsâ€”the two near the navel were serious enough to have caused death in a day or two, they perforated not only the abdominal wall, but the posterior parts, and had gone right through the stomach; such a weapon as this file would have caused themâ€”my opinion was that the punctured wounds were inflicted first; they had gone through the clothes and the stays.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I have nothing to say to your worship, and I have no witnesses here."
The two following witnesses were, at MR. PURCELL'S request, put into the box by MR. MATHEWS, but were examined by MR. PURCELL.
JOHN CHARLES JONES . I am a foreman at Hayes' Wharfâ€”the prisoner

was employed there between twelve and thirteen years, down to December, 1887â€”during the time he was working under me I observed something peculiar in his manner, he was peculiarly eccentric in his ways and manner generally; he would go about his work, and if you put a question to him, the way he would answer you, lie would take short steps and starts, and go from one place to another to do his workâ€”he would draw himself up very close in a military and soldier-like fashion, and salute me very sharp, and say, "Right, right"â€”if I sent him from one part of the building to another with some men to do some work, in all probability he would start before the other men very quick, and then stop and turn round and make an expression to the men and say, "I could do half the b----work before you get there"â€”that peculiar behaviour was at all times, but he seemed a little more so at times; that was noticeable to the men who were working with him; ho used to be called by them "Mad Bradshaw "â€”he would be sober there, or we should not allow him in the building, but at times when I saw him more eccentric than at others I should say it was from the effects of drink over-nightâ€”I could not. say that he had the appearance of a heavy drinkerâ€”beyond these peculiarities he was peaceable, well-behaved workman; he did his work satisfactorilyâ€”I did not notice anything quarrelsome in his disposition. Cross-examined. He earned on an average from 28s. to 30s. a week; it variedâ€”during the last five years he was there he was under ray charge, and I saw a good deal of himâ€”he left because he lost time; he was dis
charged on that account in December, 1887; he had worked there continuously till thenâ€”I can't say that I ever saw him drunkâ€”what I speak of as peculiar in his manner was that he had rather a military manner, he would stop and address you as such, and draw himself up in rather a military attitude and salute, and sometimes if I sent him to work I have noticed he would make a dead stop, and pull himself up to "attention "â€”I did not know that he had been in the militia seven years; I hoard so, I can't say that I knew itâ€”ho was a very good workman, and did his work quite satisfactorilyâ€”ho mixed with the men; ho was a tea cooperâ€”he would work with a weapon similar to this chopperâ€”there was nothing to suggest that he was not right in his mind.
Re-examined. Militiamen are not uncommon among the men working in the docks.

EDWIN WILDING . I am quay foreman at Butler's Wharfâ€”the prisoner has been employed there during the last four or five years, not regularly, casually, he would not lose less than throe months out of twelveâ€”he has been under my observation while employed there; he would be with me nine months out of the year; I have noticed a peculiar manner about him on several occasions, walking about the quay in a soldier-like manner, and giving peppermint lozenges to people about the quay; in fact, he has offered me someâ€”he would start box knocking, and would walk about the floor, and come back and say nothing to anybody, and start working againâ€”he has made complaints to me about his daughters and sonsâ€”he has complained about his head; he asked me to let him go to the hospital-his conduct has been noticed by the men he worked with; he was called "Mad Bradshaw "â€”that was a common phrase about Butler's Wharfâ€”that has gone on all the time he was employed there; he has been a quiet, peaceable man, not quarrel
some,

far from that, quite the other way, and a good workmanâ€”I have noticed his appearance as if recovering from the effects of drinkâ€”I saw him on the Saturday morning this happened, about ten; he was looking for work, he had nothing to do with us then, he looked rather shaky; I mean as to drink.

Cross-examined. I can't give the exact date when he was last employed at Butler's Wharf, but I think it was about a week before this happenedâ€”he had been employed there about four years from about the time he left Hayes' Wharfâ€”during that time he was employed nine months out of twelve, receiving wages during that time from 30s. to 35s. a weekâ€”he did not work the week before this; I think he was along with me on colonial work; he might work a day now and then, working with others, about two hundredâ€”for the last ten weeks he would work a day now and then; he worked as a tea cooper, but he was not particular; he would do anything, colonial work and thatâ€”I have never seen him drunk at work; we should not have allowed him there if he wasâ€”he was perfectly steady, and a good workman, far from being a lazy manâ€”it was not only his military gait that struck me, I have had occasion to speak to him about other things; he would leave his hammer on the top of a box and go and walk about the floor, and then go on with his work againâ€”that was the peculiarity I noticedâ€”he has sometimes asked me to let him go to the hospitalâ€”I could not tell that he ever went, I could not follow him; he has brought a medicine bottle backâ€”there was nothing at all dan
gerous about him, or in his mixing with other personsâ€”I have seen him drunk, but not in business hoursâ€”I saw him on the morning of 4th July standing at the corner of the street; he passed the time of day with me, that was all; I thought he had been drinkingâ€”I was going for my holiday, and I was at Brighton when I heard of thisâ€”I should think it was ten weeks or three months ago when he was last employed by the weekâ€”he was always a casual man, not a permanent oneâ€”I think he did one day's work in the week of 4th July.

Re-examined. When he was regularly working he would be employed every day if he came to look after itâ€”we don't employ men regularly; we take them from the gateâ€”it was about ten minutes to ten when I saw him on the morning of 4th Julyâ€”that would not be the time he would come to look for workâ€”he would be there before that.

PHILIP FRANCIS GILBERT . I am surgeon to H. M. Prison at Hollowayâ€”in consequence of instructions I have had the prisoner under my special observation from the date of his admission there, Monday, 6th Julyâ€”he has told me different things when I have been talking to himâ€”he has not complainedâ€”he has told me that he suffered from head
ache, and from pressure on the top of the head, from humming, and bells ringing in his head at timesâ€”he told me that for the last few years he had been under the impression that his wife was unfaithful to him, but he had no proof of it; it was merely conjectureâ€”he has been under my observation from 6th of July down to the 26thâ€”during the whole of that time his conduct has been perfectly rational and quiet, and very well-behavedâ€”I have seen nothing to indicate that he was insane; I consider him of sound mindâ€”I believe him to be able to distinguish between right and wrong, and to know when he is doing wrong.

Cross-examined. I have gathered from his history that for years he has been drinking to excessâ€”I have heard that he has been in Rother
hithe

Infirmary for gastritisâ€”intemperance is very often the cause of gastritis; of course, I don't know what that wasâ€”he is a man of low type of intellect, impaired by intemperate habitsâ€”he is certainly not an intelligent man.

Re-examined. Gastritis might be the result of other causes than in
temperance.
GUILTY .â€”
DEATH .

623.
JAMES KELLY (20)
, for the manslaughter of
Mary Ann Tobin.

CATHERINE KELLY . I am the wife of Thomas Kelly, and live at 10, Globe Street, Southwark, with the prisoner, who is my sonâ€”my husband is awayâ€”the deceased, Mary Tobin. was my sisterâ€”she lived at 2, Pro
vidence Place, eight or ten minutes' walk from meâ€”the prisoner was at home on Sunday morning, 28th Juneâ€”the deceased came in about a quarter-past twelve on Saturday night or Sunday morning with my little girlâ€”my sister must have had a little to drink; she could not have been sober, or she would not have spoken to me as she didâ€”the prisoner was very much the worse for drinkâ€”the deceased said my little girl had been in a fit, and the prisoner said, "A good job too if she was a corpse"â€”there was a wrangle, and I said to the deceased, "Come out"â€”I saw she was going too far with him, and he said, "Go out, go out"â€”I was making for the door when I saw him take a glass tumbler from the mantelpieceâ€”I don't know whether ho threw itâ€”we were jawing, and he said, "Leave me alone "â€”I went out, and when I came back I found my sister lying on the floor bleeding from her headâ€”I helped her upâ€”I did not see any blow struckâ€”there was a saucepan in the room, but it never struck my sisterâ€”please don't press me, the prisoner is a good son, quiet and inoffensiveâ€”he was invalided from the army, and a little drop of drink upsets him; he was a teetotaler.

MICHAEL TOBIN . I am a waiter, and lived with my mother, Mary Ann Tobin, at 2, Providence Alley, Long Lane, Bermondseyâ€”she was a widow, and got her living as a fur pullerâ€”the prisoner is my cousinâ€”on Saturday night, 27th June, I saw my mother, about eight, at home brushing clothesâ€”she was quite sober then and in her usual healthâ€”I went to bed shortly after twelveâ€”afterwards my mother came inâ€”I heard her growlingâ€”I got up and saw her sitting on the fender with her hand to her head; we lived in the same roomâ€”I spoke to her, find she answeredâ€”I fell asleep, and when I awoke she was lying on the floor; there was blood on her bosom and on her clothesâ€”I thought she had had a little drinkâ€”I had not noticed that when she came inâ€”I called Mrs. McCarthy, the landlady, and lifted my mother up and laid her on the bed and washed her headâ€”she only just said, "Never mind "â€”I went round to my aunt, Mrs. Kelly, and found her sitting in bed cryingâ€”I spoke to her, and she pointed to an iron saucepanâ€”I looked at it and found there was a piece out of the rimâ€”while I was there the prisoner came in; this was close on nine in the morningâ€”he was quite soberâ€”he said, "Where is your mother, Mike?"â€”I said, "You had better go and see"â€”he said, "I will come down with you "â€”he said, "All I remember is picking up a glass"â€”I asked him if he remembered throwing the potâ€”he said, "No, I was drunk; I know it did not hit her "â€”we went together to our house and found mother in bed and very illâ€”I said,

"Now she is done for, Jim"â€”he said, "I will go and fetch a doctor "â€”I went out for a walk, and when I came back I found some people had removed her to the hospitalâ€”I met the prisoner outside the hospital, and said, "I want to see my mother"â€”he said, "Come on, then"â€”he said I should have to find out how it was doneâ€”I said, "You had better get out of the way, Jim"â€”he said, "I will Mike, and I will turn drink up"â€”we then parted, and I saw nothing more of him till he was in custody.

ELLEN McCARTHY . I live at 2, Providence Placeâ€”the deceased occupied a room there; I last saw her about eleven on Saturday night, 27th Juneâ€”she was then sober, and was upstairs cleaning her roomâ€”next morning, about nine, the last witness called me up; I then found her on the bed with blood about her head and neck; she was not consciousâ€”about three the same day I saw the prisoner in the room; I said, "I little thought you had done this, Jim"â€”he said, "I did it in drink, Ellen "â€”he and young Tobin went out, and I took the deceased to the hospital.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You got a cab for me and my husband to take her to the hospital; you first went and fetched the doctorâ€”your aunt had the baby out on Saturday night between half-past six and seven; I don't know where she went.

LAURA SMITH . I am the wife of Peter Smithâ€”the prisoner lived in our house with his motherâ€”at midnight, on 27th June, I was aroused by the prisoner's sister, Mary Ann Kelly, coming into my roomâ€”as I went upstairs I met Mrs. Kelly and Mrs. Tobin coming down, Mrs. Tobin was bleeding from the head; I bathed her head in the back yardâ€”Mrs. Kelly called out to her son, "Oh, Jim, Jim, what have you done to your aunt?"â€”he replied, "Why did not you let me alone? "â€”I did not see him; I heard his voice on the stairsâ€”I did not see him till the Tuesday; I had then heard that his aunt had been removed to the hospital, and that she was dying; I told him soâ€”he said, "I don't know what I done; I was very drunk," and he cried very muchâ€”he was sober thenâ€”there are three storeys to my houseâ€”I live in the parlour, the prisoner and his mother lived at the top.

MARY ANN KELLY . I am ten years oldâ€”the prisoner is my brotherâ€”on this Saturday night when I went home there was a disturbanceâ€”my aunt said I had had a fitâ€”my brother said, "It would be a good job if she was a corpse "â€”then the two of them began having a rowâ€”I was frightened, and ran out when my brother jumped upâ€”I did not see him do anything.
Cross-examined. I never saw you have a row beforeâ€”you were always. good friends with your aunt.

THOMAS DIVELL (Sergeant M). I and Gentle arrested the prisoner at 10, Globe Street, on the 2nd July, at eleven at nightâ€”I said we were police officers, and were going to take him into custody for causing the death of his aunt on the Saturday beforeâ€”he said, "My mother told me on Sunday morning that I had done so-and-so to my aunt last night"â€”the mother was in the room at this time, and she said, "My son took up something, I don't know what it was, and struck my poor sister, who is dead "â€”on the way to the station he said, "If I have done the crime I shall have to stand by it. "
WILLIAM GENTLE (Detective M). I was with Divellâ€”while he was searching the room the prisoner said, "Tell the truth, mother, you have
told everybody else I did it; now where is the pot? "â€”she replied, "I don't know, Jim. "

HERBERT DANIEL . I am a registered medical practitioner, and house surgeon at Guy's Hospitalâ€”the deceased, Mary Tobin, was admitted there on Sunday afternoon, the 28th Juneâ€”she was rather in a dazed condition, as if suffering from the combined effects of drink and head injuryâ€”she was able to walkâ€”she had a scalp-wound on the left side, it went down to the boneâ€”it was a contused woundâ€”there was a good deal of bruisingâ€”she remained in an unconscious condition till 2nd July, when she diedâ€”I made a post-mortemâ€”the cause of death was extrava
sation of blood and laceration of the brain tissue on the right side of the base of the brainâ€”that was the result of the injuryâ€”that might have been caused either by a heavy blow or a fallâ€”I rather gave preference to a fall, because of the extensive injury to the brain tissue; I thought the weight of the body was more likely to cause that than a blowâ€”a fall from a blow would have done it; it was the result of considerable violenceâ€”there were no other bruises and no fracture; it could not have been caused by a tumbler.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, stated that he was very much in drink, and was quite ignorant of having injured the deceased.

div1.p:
GUILTY â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour,

624.
ALEXANDER HOLLIS (24)
, for the manslaughter of
Edward Wharton.

JOHN SHORT . I am a carman, and live at 2, Wallis Cottages, Garrett Lane, Wandsworthâ€”on the evening of 11th July, about a quarter or twenty minutes past eight, I was outside the Halfway Houseâ€”I saw Edward Wharton buy a peck of peas off a costermonger's barrowâ€”the prisoner was there with another young man named Whit yearâ€”they came up and asked Wharton if he was going to stand some beerâ€”he said, "No"â€”Whityear said, "We will treat you if you like"â€”he said, "No, I don't want a treat; I don't live in Garrett Lane now, I live in Rose Fields," and he struck Whityear in the faceâ€”Whityear took off his coat, and they had a stand-up fightâ€”Wharton knocked him down; as he was getting up from the ground, before he was properly on his legs, the deceased went to strike him again, and the prisoner stepped forward and gave the deceased a blow in the neck or faceâ€”I could not say which; I was standing behind themâ€”it was a hardish blow, and the deceased fell off the kerb into the main road on the back part of his headâ€”he never spoke afterwardsâ€”he was taken into the public-house, and I saw him dead there.

Cross-examined. All three of them were the worse for drinkâ€”the disturbance began by chaffing the deceased about his buying peas, he being a gardenerâ€”they said they grew better peas than he didâ€”he lost his temper, and struck Whityear in the faceâ€”no one else took any share in the fight.

ROBERT JAMES CHAPMAN . I am a clerk, and live at 42, Grosvenor Road, Camberwellâ€”on 11th July I was coming down Garrett Lane on a bicycleâ€”I stopped at a public-houseâ€”I heard a noise outside, and went

out to see what was the matterâ€”I saw the deceased having a fight with Whityearâ€”Whityear was knocked downâ€”I saw the prisoner strike Wharton in the faceâ€”it was a well directed very hard blowâ€”it knocked Wharton right off his feet on the back of his head in the roadâ€”he never moved afterwardsâ€”I picked him up, and afterwards a doctor came.

Cross-examined. I did not see the beginning of the disturbance; the noise attracted meâ€”when I came out I saw about half a dozen people fightingâ€”the deceased was standing close to the kerb on the pavement; the blow knocked him into the middle of the road.
LEWIS GARRARD . I am potman at the Halfway Houseâ€”I saw this disturbance.

Cross-examined. I saw Whityear and the deceased fighting; the prisoner was about two yards away from them; there was a general scrimmage of half a dozen persons, and sides were takenâ€”I saw a man attempt to strike the prisoner with a pipeâ€”the deceased was slightly the worse for drink.
Re-examined. I think it was after the man had fallen that somebody tried to strike the prisonerâ€”I did not see anyone do so before that; I think it was a friend of the deceased.

STANLEY CLIVE PHILLIPS . I am a registered medical practitionerâ€”on the night of 11th July, about nine, I was called to the Half way Houseâ€”I found the deceased lying on the side of the pavement, unconscious; he was carried inside, and died within two or three minutesâ€”I saw a slight abrasion on the left cheek and-outside the left ear; also a slight bruise on the posterior temple region, a slight swelling, and a scalp wound over the swelling on the back part of the headâ€”I made a post-mortem on the 13thâ€”after removing the skull-cap there was extensive hemorrhage over the surface of the brain; the base of the skull was fractured, and there was laceration of the blood vesselsâ€”that was the cause of deathâ€”the fracture would be caused by the man falling backwards on a hard surface.
Cross-examined. The body was that of a well-grown powerful man, of middle age.
PETER TRAINER (V 567). I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”he made no reply to the chargeâ€”he was sober.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy.
He received an excellent character.â€”
Discharged on his own recognisance.

625.
ALBERT DIX (32)
, Unlawfully setting fire to a warehouse belonging to
Arthur James Humphery.
The prisoner had surrendered himself on a charge of arson committed on 21st April, 1886. There was no evidence beyond his confession, and it was proved that he was subject to delusion
NOT GUILTY .

626.
THOMAS WILLIAM JACKSON (32)
, Unlawfully obtaining various sums of money from
Edgar William Cundy, by false pretences, with intent to defraud.

EDGAR WILLIAM CUNDY . I am a money-lender at 152, Westminster Bridge Roadâ€”on 26th July, 1889, the prisoner applied to me for an advance; he filled in this form of application, stating that the amount required was

Â£30, to be repaid in equal monthly instalments; security offered, furni
ture at The Laurels, 19, Stonebridge Park, Willesden; he described him
self as a paper factor, and signed the application "Thomas William Jackson "â€”he filled up this other document, consisting of questions and answers; to the question asking if the furniture was absolutely his own property the answer given is absolutely"; to the question whether any of the furniture or musical instruments were on hire and if so, from whom was it hired, the answer is, "Piano Moore and Moore,; and to the question what was the amount of his debts and liabilities, the answer is, "Owes none; about Â£5 for rates"â€”I asked him whether he owed anything for rates, and the answer he gave was Â£5â€”before advancing the money he made this statutory declaration, and signed it in my presence.(This declared that all the furniture and effects at the address given were absolutely his own, and were not charged or encumbered, and that he had full power to absolutely sell the same)â€”I then advanced him Â£30 on the security of that furniture under this agreement D, which was not intended to be registered as a bill of saleâ€”from time to time the prisoner paid off some sums on that loanâ€”on 1st August he applied for a further advance of Â£30, and he had that as a dear advance on 9th August on documents in similar form, repeating the same allegations; a statutory declaration was made in the same form again, and the money was advanced under a similar agreementâ€”on 31st January, 1890, there was a further advance of Â£35; I deducted from that the balance owing on the first loan of 26th Julyâ€”he made a declaration and agreement in the same formâ€”on 8th August, 1890, I made a further advance of Â£80â€”a balance was then taken between us, and he paid off the remainder of the second and third loans, and he received the balanceâ€”that advance was made on this bill of sale in the regular form which he signed in my presence, "Thomas William Jackson"; by it he assigns in ordinary form the whole of this fur
niture to meâ€”he has since paid Â£27 19s. 6d. off the Â£80â€”at the time the bill of sale was made the furniture was at 33, Church Road, Richmondâ€”I knew the prisoner had removed thereâ€”he is still described as a paper agent in the bill of saleâ€”I never saw the furniture; I sent my managerâ€”I knew the prisoner afterwards removed to Claphamâ€”in consequence of information 1 re
ceived, I charged him.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I have been a money-lender five or six yearsâ€”I advance money generally by cheques, which are proof of the advances, and I take no receiptsâ€”I take either a bill of sale or promissory note as securityâ€”of these three documents one is a bill of sale and three are hiring agreementsâ€”I first used bills of sale, and then I thought hiring agreements would do; but when I found they would not I went back to bills of saleâ€”these hiring agreements are on printed forms; my solicitor drew up the draftâ€”I have many other such agreementsâ€”I keep for the purpose printed forms, which set out that it is a purchase by me of the furniture detailed in the schedule in the first place, and then a hiring of the goods by youâ€”I certainly thought at the time that I had bought the goods in the schedule; I intended to do soâ€”I sent to take an inventory of them; I never saw them. (Mr. AVORY stated that the legal effect of these hiring agreements had been decided by the Court of Appear and that in consequence of that decision the use of them had been discontinued.â€”my clerk filled in the scheduleâ€”the cheques are endorsed; you received the

money for themâ€”on 26th July I sent my clerk to the bank with the cheque, and he brought back the money, and the whole Â£30 was handed to youâ€”on 9th August you had the Â£30 in fullâ€”on 31st January you paid me back Â£10, and had Â£25 out of the Â£35 advanceâ€”on 8th August, 1890, you paid me Â£40 15s., the balance of the second and third loans, and received in cash for the bill of sale Â£39 5s.â€”I cannot identify the furniture.

EDWARD LAW . I am valuer to Mr. Cundyâ€”I took an inventory of the furniture at 19, Stonebridge Parkâ€”in August, 1890, I went to Church Road, Richmond, and saw the same furnitureâ€”this is my book contain
ing the inventoryâ€”afterwards, in this year, I think about May, I went to 24, The Chase, Clapham Common, where the prisoner was then living, and saw the same furniture that I had seen before at Willesden and Richmondâ€”I saw the prisoner's wife there, I do not think I saw himâ€”I put a man in possession, and then I took him out, I thought it would be best to give the prisoner a chance of settling with the officeâ€”I went again, and found the place locked up; no one answered the door, and. apparently no one was in the house; I heard a dog barkingâ€”in con
sequence of inquiries I made, I went to the Tower Famishing Company, and received information from themâ€”I have since been to Rugg's Furniture Depository at Clapham, and I have recognised there some furniture which is contained in this inventory and in documents V and Wâ€”I have also been to Taylor's Furniture Depositoryâ€”I there saw the furniture mentioned in this documentâ€”I also identified the furniture pledged with Attenborough as having been contained in the inventory.

Cross-examined. I produce one inventory for all four transactionsâ€”I did not see your furniture before 26th July, 1889; it was later in the year when I first went to your houseâ€”I did not take the inventory in the first place; another witness took it; I only went and checked it afterwardsâ€”I did not take this inventory of August, 1889; I took no inventory in 1889â€”I think I first checked the inventory in December, 1890â€”it was correctâ€”I knew nothing of the transactions till thenâ€”I saw the furniture in your house at Willesden and at Richmond, and have identified it with the furniture named in the scheduleâ€”the schedules are all dated before December, 1890, when I first saw it.

Re-examined. I went to 19, Stonebridge Park, Willesden, and saw the prisoner living there, and saw his furniture on 28th January, 1889, and I went to his place at Richmond in 1890, and saw the same furniture.

JOHN AUGUSTUS MORGAN ROBERTSON . I am an accountant, at Stock
well nowâ€”I was in Mr. Cundy's employment, and left him in February, 1890â€”I was present on 26th July, 1889, when the prisoner borrowed money of himâ€”I went to Willesden and took an inventory of the furniture, which is embodied in the form of a schedule to the agreement of 26th Julyâ€”the prisoner signed that scheduleâ€”I saw the prisoner again in August, 1889, when the second advance was made; I went to Willesden and saw the furniture there again; the furniture in the two schedules, D and F, is the same; they are copies; but the second con
tains bedroom furniture not in the first.
Cross-examined. The inventories I made are in the books in the officeâ€”they were copied on to the schedules, and signed by you.
ROBERT AUGUSTUS PANSHAW . I am manager to the Tower Furnishing Company, of 43, Great Tower Streetâ€”I recognise the prisoner; I was

present when he signed an agreement for the hire of certain furniture from our company on 11th March, 1887; I witnessed itâ€”it contained a schedule in the ordinary form, that the furniture is to belong to us till all instalments are paidâ€”on 28th January, 1889, I was present when the prisoner hired more furniture of the company; that agreement also con
tains a schedule; I cannot identify the furniture contained in it.

HENRY ALGERNON BOTHON . I am in the service of the Tower Furnish
ing Companyâ€”I saw the prisoner when he hired furniture of the com
panyâ€”I have since seen him from time to time at the company's officesâ€”I know he moved to Richmond, and afterwards to Claphamâ€”we had it duly noted in our ledgerâ€”in July, 1889, he had not paid off all the ins
stalments due under these agreements, nor has he up to now; the com
pany claim the furniture under the agreementsâ€”on 20th August, 1890, I saw in Perry's Gazette a notice that he had given a bill of sale; I had a letter written to him, and on the 21st he came in answer to the letterâ€”I sent a clerk to him with the Gazette, and I walked up and heard what was saidâ€”the Gazette was shown to him; he was asked, "What does this mean: a bill of sale registered against Thomas William Jackson? "â€”he said, "It was not I that gave the bill of sale at all, it was my brother"â€”the names being different I did not listen to any moreâ€”we knew him by the name of Thomas Absolom Carew Jackson.

Cross-examined. I cannot identify the furniture in these schedulesâ€”I will swear you did not say, "Do you think it is my brother?"â€”what was said was in my hearing, not to meâ€”I produce the accountsâ€”the first agreement was in October, 1886â€”the first payment was in December, 1886, and the last on February 10th, 1891â€”on the first hiring agreement in 1886 you paid Â£79; on the agreement dated 2nd March, 1887, Â£58 18s.; on the agreement with the Tower Furnishing Company, of January, you have paid Â£2 9s.â€”the first agreement in 1886 was for Â£265 10s., to be repaid by monthly payments of Â£10, and should have been cleared off in 1888; it took from December, 1886, to November, 1890, to pay off the Â£79â€”we placed the matter in Messrs Chadwick's hands to collect from time to timeâ€”the agreement of March, 1887, was for Â£74 17s., to be repaid in monthly instalments of Â£2 5s., which should have taken about thirty months: Â£58 18s. has been paid.
Re-examined. The prisoner signed his name, Thomas A. C. Jackson, to the agreements.

HENRY WILLIAM PALMER . I am an auctioneer and managing clerk to Messrs. Chadwickâ€”I went to Rugg's and Taylor's Depositories, taking this schedule and inventory with me, and I recognised there some of the furniture described in these lists, and identified it with that supplied by the Tower Furnishing Company, for whom I actedâ€”I have tried to collect certain instalments from the prisoner, I have collected someâ€”the furniture at Taylor's had been pledged with Attenborough's.

Cross-examined. The goods I saw answered the description in the schedule, and I knew them by the character, style, and makeâ€”I am sure the things described were what I saw, and I have since had them delivered up to me under the company's claim, and I have sold themâ€”I had not seen the furniture before; we took possession of it several times.
Re-examined. Rugg delivered up the furniture to us, and I have sold it by auction; Attenborough is keeping his till this trial is over.
GEORGE HINCTILIFFE . I am foreman at Rugg's Depository, Clapham

â€”on 7th February, 1891, I went to 24, The Chase, Clapham Common, to value some furniture the prisoner wished to dispose ofâ€”I saw him thereâ€”I purchased a walnut suite for Â£8; it is set out in this list Vâ€”I took it to our depositoryâ€”the prisoner signed this document in my presence. (This was signed" Thomas Jackson" and certified that there was no bill of sale of any hind on the goods purchased, and that they were his own property abso
lutely.)â€”on 16th March, 1891, I bought some more furniture of him for Â£5â€”they are the goods in the list Wâ€”he made a similar declaration that there was no bill of sale on themâ€”we have since given up that furniture to Messrs. Chadwick, who claimed it on behalf of the Tower Furnishing Company.
Cross-examined, We were advised to give it up as it was their propertyâ€”you sold the furniture to us on the condition that you had the power to buy it back at the end of three months.

ALFRED TIMBERLAKE . I am a collector to the London and Provincial Furnishing Company, Tottenham Court Roadâ€”on 24th January, 1889, the prisoner had some furniture on hire from the companyâ€”this is the agree
ment, with the schedule of the furnitureâ€”it is signed "Thomas Jackson"â€”in July, 1889, and in August, 1890, the instalments had not all been paidâ€”about February, 1891, I saw the prisoner at 24, The Chase, Clap
ham Common, for the purpose of getting some money, and I told him we should remove the goods under our agreement if he did not payâ€”he said things had been very bad, and he would send some money onâ€”afterwards I went to Rugg's Depository, and there I saw some of the furniture mentioned in this agreement.

JOSEPH LEOPOLD BERNSTEIN . I am manager of the London and Pro
vincial Furnishing Companyâ€”on 24th January, 1889, the prisoner had some furniture on hireâ€”he gave the address 19, Stonebridge Park, "Willesden, and described himself as an advertising agentâ€”he signed this agreement in my presence; money is still due under it.

Cross-examined. Nobody witnessed the agreementâ€”you have paid Â£69 3s., I believeâ€”the receipts, which are printed only, say "On account of furnitureâ€”this agreement has not been the subject of a legal decision since I have been in the firm, four or five yearsâ€”Mr. Roberts brought an action against us lately, to recover damages for improperly seizing furniture acquired under a hire and purchase agreementâ€”he introduced an agreement similar to us; the verdict was against us for Â£65.
Re-examined. There were other points in connection with the caseâ€”it turned on a question of debt; we had seized the furniture.

HERBERT ATTENBOROUGH . I am a pawnbroker, at 81, Walworth Roadâ€”this pawn-ticket relates to furniture at Taylor's Depository, on which we advanced Â£6, 20th March, 1891, to the prisoner in the name of Henry Maxwell, 31, Southampton Street, Strandâ€”the Tower Furnishing Com
pany have since claimed itâ€”it was at Taylor's Depository when the prisoner applied for the advance on it.

Cross-examined. We have not delivered it upâ€”you signed this declar
ation that it was yoursâ€”I have not given them up, because there is a double claim on them.

ALFRED NICHOLLS (Detective L). I arrested the prisoner on 16th April on a warrant, which I read to him; it was for obtaining Â£80 on a fraudulent bill of saleâ€”he said, "I did not expect they would do this "â€”on the way to the station he said, "In June, 1890, I made an agree
ment

with the Tower Furnishing Company, that for services I was to render with reference to a director, I was to receive the sum of Â£300 in the autumn of that year; and it was during that interval, whilst waiting to receive the money, and being in want of ready money, that I gave the bill of sale on the goods, intending to pay it back out of the Â£300 that the company owes me "â€”I searched him at the station, and found a con
tract note for furniture pledged at Attenborough's, 81, Walworth Road, a receipt for Â£3 on the London and Provincial Furniture Company, another receipt for furniture at Taylor's Depository, and a receipt for a quarter's rent, at 24, The Chase, Clapham Common, and a number of pawn-tickets relating to clothingâ€”I asked the prisoner if the furniture pledged at Attenborough's belonged to the Tower Furnishing Companyâ€”he said, "Yes," but that the receipt from the London and Provincial Company related to another transaction.

Cross-examined. I read the evidence I have just given to you at the police-station after putting it downâ€”I gave the evidence at the Police-courtâ€”you did not tell me the bill of sale was invalidâ€”you told me you received Â£38, and that that was not the full amount of the consideration money of the bill of sale.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, contended that all the documents were illegal; that he believed the furniture was his, and that he had no intention to defraud.

div1.p: HENRY LOVETT . I am a solicitorâ€”I brought an action against you in December, 1888, on account of the Tower Company, for instalments due; judgment was given against you in defaultâ€”the money was paid during a period of some months.

ROBERT AUGUSTUS PANSHAW (Re-examined by the prisoner). This letter of 30th June, 1890, is authentic; it was given to you, and is to the effect that in consideration of your being able to induce Mr. Andrew Walker, of the Bovril Company, to join a company we were connected with, you were to have Â£300 on the company going to allotmentâ€”no services had been rendered at that time; you had procured Mr. Walker to go on optionally; you had not fulfilled your part; you had to wait till the company went to allotmentâ€”I put his name on the prospectus; I did not use the prospectus to procure money; it was a confidential prospectus, used for the purpose of underwritingâ€”the names of the directors were put into the prospectus after the letter was given to youâ€”you had nothing else to do to earn the money, except wait till the com
pany wont to allotmentâ€”the two gentlemen whose names I put on the prospectus remained on the board optionally for four months; they gave me no reason for going offâ€”I do not know that you were responsible for his withdrawalâ€”I paid him no moneyâ€”we did not seize the furniture, because we were giving you advertisements at the time, and I knew your employer very well; and by sueing you we could attach your commission.

GUILTY .â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: There were other indictments against the prisoner.

div1.p:
627.
JOHN WAGGETT (32)
, Feloniously wounding
Henrietta Wood house, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

HENRIETTA WOODHOUSE . I live at 4, Trinity Place, Boroughâ€”I am a widowâ€”I used to live with the prisoner as his wife up to Mayâ€”on the evening of 13th July I went on an errand with Mrs. Rattenboroughâ€”the prisoner came up to me and. said, "I thought you were going to bed"â€”I said I did but I could not sleep, and I got up againâ€”we three walked together the length of the street, and when we got to the corner of Swan Street he struck me on the face with his right handâ€”I fell against the railingsâ€”he then put his left arm round my neckâ€”he had something bright and sharp in his right hand; it struck me in the throatâ€”I Could not see what it wasâ€”I ran screamingâ€”the prisoner walked down Cole Streetâ€”I saw a constable, and told him, and he took me to the station.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. The Inspector asked me if I saw any
thing in prisoner's hand, and I said yesâ€”I stopped all Sunday night with youâ€”you slept on a couch and I sat in a chair, to save my lifeâ€”I did not ask you to marry me, nor did you say you could not because my husband was aliveâ€”I said I would never live-with you againâ€”I don't know that my husband is aliveâ€”the policeman has the earring that I wore on this night; the earring did not break and cut my neck when you put your arm round meâ€”I was not friends with you since Mayâ€”I was obliged to seem soâ€”you said you would, kill me if I did not go along with you.

JULIA RATTENBOROUGH . I am the wife of George Rattenborough, of 2, Mercia Court, Crediton Placeâ€”I know the prosecutrix and the prisonerâ€”I was with her on 13th July when the prisoner rushed out of Cole Street and said, "I thought you were going to bed"â€”she said she was going with me on an errandâ€”I left them at the cornerâ€”I came back in about two minutes, and the three of us walked through Cole Street to Swan Corner, when the prisoner struck her on the side of the face with his fistâ€”he then put his left arm round her neck, and in his right hand I saw something very bright, and Mrs. Woodhouse bleeding very muchâ€”I saw him go in that fashion (a blow)â€”she struggled and ran awayâ€”the prisoner ran up Cole Street.

JOHN RYE . I live at 3, Swan Place, Boroughâ€”I know the prisoner by sightâ€”I saw him and the prosecutrix at the corner of Cole Street, and saw him strike her with his fist; she fell against the railingsâ€”he then put his left arm round her neck and drew a sharp instrument across her throatâ€”she. put her handkerchief up to her neck; I saw a out thereâ€”she screamed and ran down Swan Place, and he walked down Cole Street.

Cross-examined. You had the razor in your right handâ€”I did not see where you took it fromâ€”I saw the earring break and fall down by the side of the, railingâ€”I did not absolutely see the razor, it was a thick instrument.

CHARLES BOSLEY (Sergeant M 22). I received information from the prosecutrix's son, and took the prisoner onto custodyâ€”he said, "Oh," and laughed when I told him the chargeâ€”on the way to the station he said, "You need not lead me, I will go "â€”the charge was read to him at the station, he made; no answer to itâ€”I searched him, but found no instrument upon him; that was about three-quarters of an hour after the offence was committed
WILLIAM SWORDS (Inspector M). I was at the station about half-past eight when the prisoner was brought inâ€”the prosecutrix was there; she

detailed the circumstancesâ€”I then told him lie would be charged with attempted murderâ€”he said, "Why, I am living with her"â€”I said, "She says she wants to get rid of you"â€”he said, "Well, I was there last night "â€”she said, "Yes, I allowed you to stop, to save my life"â€”he said nothing furtherâ€”the vest he had on had spots of blood on it, but I don't think they had reference to this caseâ€”he said, "Do you know what that is?"â€”I said, "Yes, blood," but it was inside.
Cross-examined. I saw your head; it had a wound, that had occurred a few days previously; you had a card from Guy's Hospital.

THOMAS EVANS . I am surgeon to the M Divisionâ€”I examined the prosecutrix on the evening of the 13thâ€”I found an incised wound on the upper and left side of the neck, an inch and a half long and about a quarter of an inch deep; it was not dangerous, it might be caused by a razorâ€”I don't think it could have been caused by this earring (produced).
Prisoner's Statement: "I had no razor; the earring is the thing that must have cut her. If I had meant to do her any harm I could have done it while I was at her place. "

GUILTY
of unlawfully wounding. â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

628.
THOMAS BROWN (34)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
James Mason Champneys, and stealing a bottle of brandy and other articles.

JAMES MASON CHAMPNEYS . I keep the Dulwich Wood House Tavern, Sydenham Hillâ€”on Friday night, 19th June, I closed the house about a quarter-past twelve, and went to bed about a quarter to one, leaving all secureâ€”about half-past four in the morning I was awoke by a noise downstairsâ€”I listened, and afterwards got out of bed and lifted my window looking out into the garden, and I saw the prisoner and another man in the gardenâ€”the other man had a bagâ€”I had known them beforeâ€”the prisoner had been in the house once or twice in the course of Friday, and he had been in before thatâ€”I had seen him as a customer for a twelvemonthâ€”he came perhaps once in six monthsâ€”I should not think he came to the house more than three or four times in a twelvemonthâ€”I called out, and they ran awayâ€”this was about ten minutes to fiveâ€”I then went down and examined the premisesâ€”I found the bar shutters and the window partly downâ€”some boxes of cigars had been taken down from the shelves and emptied; I missed about 150â€”in the summer-house in the garden I found two bottles of spirits, my propertyâ€”they had not been openedâ€”I saw a ladder close to the bar window where they had got inâ€”my sons got up and searched with meâ€”I found this knife in the bar; it does not belong to meâ€”I went outside and spoke to a constableâ€”I picked up these two pieces of matches.
By the JURY. I saw the prisoner's face fully; when I called out they turned round and faced meâ€”I swear positively he is the man.

WILLIAM REED (Sergeant P). From information received I took the prisoner into custody between eleven and twelve on Saturday morning, 20th June, close to the prosecutor's houseâ€”I was with another officerâ€”before that I saw the prisoner in Wells Road, and when he got to the house he turned and looked at the bar window, which had been openedâ€”at that time the landlord's son spoke to me; the prisoner had then dis
appeared; we searched about, and afterwards found him by the tavern,

and took him into custodyâ€”I told him I should take him into-custody for committing a burglary, with another man, at Dulwich Wood Tavern that morningâ€”he said, "I am innocent; I have not been near the house; does the landlord say he see me?"â€”I said, "Yes; he says you were in the bar yesterday afternoon with another man, and did not leave till about half-past five; and about half-past four this morning he says he saw you go from the same window down the path, the other man carrying a sack"â€”he said, "I was in bed at that time; I went home at five last night, and did not go out again till a man came to speak to me about four this morning; I did not go out till ten; my wife will say the same; I also saw Mr. Duff the same morning"â€”I afterwards saw his wifeâ€”I after
wards told the prisoner that his wife said he was at home at eight the night before, but she could not and would not like to say he was at home all night or notâ€”he said, "That is all right; of course you did not tell her what time the burglary took place, and that you were police officers"â€”I said, "No, I did not; I told her what you asked me to inquire about, and that we were policemen"â€”the prisoner lives about ten minutes' walk from the prosecutor; walking leisurelyâ€”I afterwards took off the prisoner's boots, which I produce; they are considerably worn, the soles are pretty well goneâ€”I found footmarks in the garden at the place pointed out to me by the prosecutor, where he saw the two men get over the fence, also at the bottom of the gardenâ€”I took the boots there and made impressions on each side of the footprints, and found they were similarâ€”the left boot has a hole-in it, and that impression corresponded with the footprintâ€”I afterwards examined the premises, and found the entry had been effected by placing a ladder against the bar window, which was left unfastened, and by crawling in at the top and forcing the shutter down, which was fastened in the centre by a screwâ€”the foot
marks were in the private part of the garden.

Cross-examined. I lost sight of you as you turned the corner; at first we were about to make a rush at you, but missed you, and then after searching the garden we found you coming out of the side; there is a urinal thereâ€”I found the footmarks of two personsâ€”the mould was dry. Re-examined. I searched the prisoner and found five matches on him, similar to those produced by the prosecutorâ€”there were dirty finger
marks on each.

JOSEPH FULLER (Detective P). I assisted in taking the prisonerâ€”on the way to the station he pointed out a man named Horn, and said, "That man can prove where I was last night; ask him what he knows about me"â€”I afterwards saw Horn, and told the prisoner the result of my conversation with himâ€”I said, "Horn says you were in the Dulwich Wood Tavern at 7.30 last night "â€”the prisoner said, "It is false"â€”at the prisoner's request I saw the man Duff, and after seeing him I said to the prisoner, "I have seen Duff, and he denies being with you at eight this morning"â€”the prisoner said, "I did not say I saw Duff this morning; I said I saw Dick Whittingdon "â€”I am sure he did say he saw Duff at eight on Friday morningâ€”another officer was with me at the time.

p.hi: The prisoner handed in a written defence, stating that he had been at work as a carpenter for Messrs. Dove, builders, and had been with a man named Duff looking for work on the day in question; that he returned home about half-past eight, and did not go out till ten the next morning.

div1.p: EMMA. TAYLOR . I am married, and live at 19, Fir Street, Upper Sydenhamâ€”the prisoner lived in the game houseâ€”on Friday night, 19th June, I saw: him about half-past seven, or from that till eight, in: the houseâ€”that was the last I saw of him that night; and about half-past four in the morning I heard my husband call him, and I heard him' answer, "I shall not get up this morning, having nothing to go to"â€”I was not at home when he left that morningâ€”I left home at half-past eight to go go work.

Cross-examined. The prisoner is a carpenterâ€”he gets up of a morning as his work requiresâ€”he never goes out so early as half-past fourâ€”he was out of employment at this time; he had been doing a little off and onâ€”I think he had a little job the week previousâ€”it was at the time of the lock-out in Londonâ€”my husband called him to wake him upâ€”he was not always called so early; sometimes he was, and sometimes my husband would forget.

GEORGE TAYLOR . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”on Friday, 19th June, I saw the prisoner at home about nine, and he never went out before eight in the morning; I called him at half-past four, and he said ho was not going to get up, he had got nowhere to go.

Cross-examined. I have part of the house; the prisoner lives upstairs and I live downâ€”I am a labourer; I am not always in regular workâ€”I was mowing at this timeâ€”I went to work-at-half-past four or soon afterâ€”I was in bed when the prisoner came homeâ€”no one lives in the house but ourselves and the prisoner and his wife and childrenâ€”we have a back door and a front doorâ€”the rent of the house is 7s. 6d. a week.
NOT GUILTY .

629.
WILLIAM SEARLE (19) and
SIDNEY BUCKINGHAM (19)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Robert Knight, and stealing a revol
ver and other articles, to which SEARLE
PLEADED' GUILTY .

TOM BLAKE (V 370). On 14th July, at 4.15 a.m., I was in Leathwaite Road, Battersea, and a gentleman called my attention to 131, Wakehurst Roadâ€”I went there and saw through the window the two prisoners in the front parlourâ€”it was quite daylightâ€”I went to "the front, and the next door neighbour, who called me, went to the backâ€”the prisoners both came to the window and saw me; Buckingham stood at the window quite two seconds, and then went to the back of the house and over the garden wallâ€”the gentleman told me which way they had gone, and I ran and saw Buckingham getting over a wallâ€”I lost sight of him, but I can swear he is the manâ€”Searle was handed over to me.

ROBERT KNIGHT . I am an engineer, of 131, Wakehurst Road, Wands
worth Commonâ€”on 11th July I went to Sheerness, leaving my house locked upâ€”on the 14th I received a telegram, came to town, and found my house in charge of the policeâ€”the scullery door was broken, and I saw chisel marks on it, and on the windowâ€”all the doors inside the house had been forced except two, which was not necessary, as they got in by another doorâ€”all the articles were taken out of the drawers, which had been forcedâ€”these articles (produced) belong to me, and were safe in the drawers, when I left; they were lying on a bed.

GEORGE FELLOWS (Detective V). On 15th July I went with Mr. Knight to his houseâ€”an entrance had been effected by the back kitchen door by forcing the boxâ€”the parlour door had been forcedâ€”a gentleman in the

same road handed me this jemmy, which corresponds exactly with the marks on the doors, drawers, and boxesâ€”on the following Tuesday, about 2.30 a.m., I saw Buckingham in Earlsfield Road, which is about a mile from Wakehurst Roadâ€”when he got close to me he started running; we pursued him and caught him; he said, "What is the matter now? What have I done?"â€”I told him he would be charged with a man already in custody for burglary at 131, Wakehurst Road; he said he did not know where it wasâ€”I took him to the station; he was placed with six others, and Blake picked him outâ€”the Inspector read the change; he made no reply.

WILLIAM STEPHENS (D 186). On 15th July, about 2.30 a.m., I was in Earlsfield Road with Fellows, standing in a gateway, and as soon as Buckingham came near us he ran as hard as he couldâ€”we chased him 150 yards, and I caught him by his coat.

SAMUEL CLARK . I live at 129, Wakehurst Road, which is next door to No. 131â€”I know Mr. Knight, and was keeping an eye on his house while he was away at the seasideâ€”on this Tuesday morning about 4.30 I was in bed and heard a noise next doorâ€”I got up, went to the front of the house, looked under the Venetian blinds, and saw a man pass from the front to the back roomâ€”I cannot say who it wasâ€”I saw Blake, and held my hand upâ€”after a conversation with him I went through my house to the back, and saw two men come out of the door opposite my doorâ€”I could see their hats, but could not see their faces distinctlyâ€”I now know that one of them was Searle.

JOHN BUCKINGHAM . I am the prisoner's fatherâ€”he lives with me at Pendennis House, Buckhurst Roadâ€”on 14th July I came home at 8.30 p.m., and wanted my son to do something for me, but I was told he had gone to bed, as he was not very wellâ€”I did not see himâ€”I went into his room at six o'clock next morning and saw him in bed.

AGNES BUCKINGHAM . I am the prisoners sister, and live with my father, the last witnessâ€”on Tuesday, 14th July, I went in to the Prisoner's room to call him at a quarter before five, and saw him in bedâ€”I did not see him go to bed.
Cross-examined. I am Searle's cousin.
ROBERT KNIGHT (Re-examined). Buckhurst Road is a mile and a half or a mile and five-eighths from Wakehurst Road.

BUCKINGHAMâ€”
GUILTY *â€ .â€”
Twelve Month' Hard Labour.
SEARLEâ€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.

630.
JAMES NEWTON (20)
, Unlawfully attempting to commit burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Redhouse.

FEANCIS PIKE (B 511). On 16th June, about a quarter to two a.m., I was on duty in Gordon Road, Battersea Road, and saw the prisoner come under a lamp-post and pull something like this (a jemmy) from his sleeve; he then went back and joined the other two at the door of a house, and I heard something clickâ€”the prisoner then left them at the door, and came under the lamp-post, buttoned up his coat, and looked up Battersea Park right and leftâ€”they could not see meâ€”I heard some one coming, and they all three left and went on the opposite side of the roadâ€”I walked to the end of Warrener Gardens, turned my light on, and

another constable came and got into the same position as I was in firstâ€”the prisoner came straight across the road to the same door, picked up the jemmy, and had another try, and it went click againâ€”No. 237 went to the bottom of Park Road by my instructionsâ€”the men found they could not get in at that door, and they all walked down the roadâ€”I fol
lowed them and signalledâ€”I saw the prisoner put his arm over some palings of a garden, and then they got awayâ€”No. 236 took the prisoner in custody, and we had a struggle in the roadâ€”he kicked me in the knee and got away, leaving his coat in my handsâ€”I found this wedge (pro
duced) about the middle of the door of the house, where it closes.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I heard the click after you came back, but you did it yourself the first timeâ€”I saw you all three go away to
getherâ€”I saw nothing thrown away, but I saw you put your hand over the palings.

NATHAN LEE (Police Inspector v). From information I received I went to the garden referred to and found this jemmyâ€”I found marks on the door, such as would be produced by this jemmy; it fitted it exactly.

FREDRICK MILWARD (V 236). On 18th June, at 1.45, I saw the light of Pike's lamp, and went to Gordon Roadâ€”I kept observation for a few minutes, and saw the prisoner come into Battersea Park Road; he looked each way to see if he could see anyone coming, and then went back and joined the other men who were standing at the side door of the Park Tavernâ€”he picked up something from the doorstep, and I heard the door clickâ€”I then went through Gordon Road and Austin Road, and saw Pike's bightâ€”I went up the road, and met the prisoners half wayâ€”I drew my truncheon, and told them to stop or I should strike themâ€”I met three men; one of them said, "What is this for? "We have done nothing "â€”I took the prisoner, and the other constable took the other twoâ€”on the way to the station the prisoner became very violent, put his feet between mine, and attempted to throw meâ€”the others got away.
Cross-examined. I did not catch you when I saw you forcing the door, because there was a possibility of your getting awayâ€”I was thirty-five yards from you.

JOSEPH REDHOUSE . I keep the Grove Tavern, Battersea Park Roadâ€”on June 18th I was called up by the police, and went down and let the Inspector inâ€”I examined the door, and found marks corresponding with this jemmy.

Prisoners Defence. The constables could not get the right one, and they determined to take someone, and took me. One witness says he saw me forcing the door at the time the constable says he saw me stand
ing at the corner.

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of housebreaking and larceny at the South London Sessions on October 14th, 1889, in the name of William Sullivan, having then been previously convicted.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

631.
JOHN WILSON (25)
, Robbery with violence on
Thomas Cooper, and stealing a watch and chain from him.
THOMAS COOPER . I am a printing-machine minder, living at 16,

Brunswick Street, Stamford Streetâ€”on 28th June, about half-past eleven, I was close to where I live in Stamford Street, at the top of Cornwall Road; I was perfectly soberâ€”just as I was going to put my foot on the kerb, three or four young fellows who were together sur
rounded and got hold of me by the throat, and pulled me to the ground, and tried to steal my watch and chainâ€”the prisoner was the man that got hold of me by the throat, and put his knees into my stomachâ€”the prisoner assisted to get me on the ground; he helped the others to knock me downâ€”he hit me in the ribs when I was on the ground; the prisoner put his knee into my stomach, and got one hand on my throat, and took my watch and chain out of my pocket with the other handâ€”I had marks on my throat; I did not look at my ribsâ€”the men were disturbed by a South-Western Railway detective, and ran awayâ€”I followed the prisoner through Salutation Place, and caught him at the bottom of Thames Streetâ€”he threw my watch awayâ€”I saw my chain in his hand; it was in seven or eight piecesâ€”as I followed him across Cornwall Road into Church Terrace, after he had come back through Salutation Place, he said to me, "If you give me your name and address I will do another deal, and pay you for your chain; you have got your watch back, you picked it up"â€”I did pick it upâ€”I saw a constable a quarter of an hour after it happened, and gave the prisoner in chargeâ€”the chain was picked up at the end of Thames Streetâ€”these are my watch and chain.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. The glass of the watch is not brokenâ€”you threw it in the road; I cannot say why it did not breakâ€”I stopped to pick my watch up at the bottom of Thames Streetâ€”I gave it to the Inspectorâ€”I did not give it to him to secure a witnessâ€”I caught you.
Re-examined. The prisoner threw the watch away twenty yards from where he knocked me down.

JAMES MCGOVAN (London and South-Western Railway Constable). At a quarter to twelve p.m. on Sunday, 28th June, I was in Cornwall Road on my way home, and saw a crowd of people, and received informationâ€”I saw the prisoner running through Salutation Place, and the prosecutor and two or three after himâ€”I stopped the prisoner, and at the same time Jenner seized him by the armâ€”he was accused of the theft; he made no replyâ€”a man gave me a watch and part of the chain, which I placed in my pocketâ€”I assisted the constable to the station, where the prisoner was charged; he made no reply there.

CHARLES JENNER (L 66). About a quarter to twelve on 28th June I was in Waterloo Road on duty; a communication was made to me, in consequence of which I went to Cornwall Road, and then to Thames Street, where I received informationâ€”I went to Salutation Place and arrested the prisonerâ€”the prosecutor gave him into custody and charged him; he made no replyâ€”I took him to the station; he made no reply to the charge there.

Cross-examined. You were walking through the passage with McGovanâ€”you were half-way through when I apprehended youâ€”McGovan had not hold of you, but was following a few paces behind you, just about to catch you; the three of you were walking.
THOMAS COOPER (Re-examined by the COURT). I suffered pain in my throat, but I was not ill; I went to work next morning.
JAMES MCGOVAN (Re-examined by the COURT). When I first entered the
court I saw the prisoner running, and afterwards he ceased running; Jenner did not see him till he had ceased running.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, denied any knowledge of the matter, and said he was walking along when the prosecutor seized and charged him.

div1.p:
GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY* to a conviction of felony in September, 1890.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

632.
HENRY ATTWOOD (17)
PLEADED GUILTY
to having carnal connection with
Annie Tassell, a girl under sixteen.

p.hi:
stated that since the prisoner's committal he had married the prosecutrix.â€”
Discharged on recognisances.

div1.p:
633.
ALFRED TRENT,
Unlawfully carnally knowing
Bertha Dawson, aged thirteen years and eleven months.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: informed the prisoner that he was discharged without a stain on his character.

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 14TH, 1891.
